4.  Phạm thị Liên (31) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


5.  Lê thị Thu (35) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


6.  Nguyễn Thị Minh (16) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


7.  Lê thị Chiến (14) là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


8.  Lê Phạm thị Hợp (22) là 21 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets,

loans.name: Maureen Salaguste Group

texts.en:
Maureen S. is from the village of Dicoloc, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Maureen is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are both collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Maureen S. Group'.

Maureen is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Maureen owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maureen has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1100 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maureen joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maureen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maureen is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Maureen from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: An

texts.en:
Mrs. An T. is a middle-aged woman whose husband we see in this photo. An T. works as a sewing laborer in the garment factory and gets a specific salary to help support her family. She has a life partner in her husband who works repairing sewing machines with her in the same industry. The couple married years ago but doesn’t have any children yet. 

An T. said she faces a problem: she gets to work by taking a taxi or walking because she hasn't her own vehicle. She has been planning to own one but she lacks money to buy one. Therefore, An T. is applying for a loan so she can afford to purchase a used motorbike to ride to her work location.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike.

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 52 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Jessie owns and operates a business making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling ice cream and "halo-halo" (a popular Filipino dessert that is a mixture of shaved ice and milk to which are added various boiled sweet beans and fruits, and served cold) to the local community. Jessie has been engaged in his business for over a year now.

Jessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Jessie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jessie is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Jessie from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Salma M. lives in Borewala, Pakistan's 'city of shrines'. Her husband is a street hawker and sells the snacks on his bicycle, while her son has rented a shop in the market where he does embroidery works. In order to financially support her husband, Salma started a cloth-selling business a few years ago. She travels to Faisalabad (famous for its textile industry) to buy clothes and sells them to the local market and other people on order. Unfortunately, these days she is out of stock. She has therefore applied for a loan from Asasah which she will use to buy clothes in bulk and of the latest variety.

Note: "Salma is showing her husband's business of snack-selling in this photo".

loans.use: To purchase clothes for reselling.

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
Jesus P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 58 years old, married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Jesus owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice to sell. He has been engaged in this business for more than a few years.

In 2009, Jesus joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Jesus has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jesus is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. He also plans to buy a pig to raise. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jesus from CEVI. He plans to improve his business by reinvesting the additional revenue generated.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure.

loans.name: Hiedeliza

texts.en:
Hiedeliza S. is from the village of Babatangan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 49 years old, married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Hiedeliza owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing transportation services to local community members. Hiedeliza has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2010, Hiedeliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Hiedeliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to pay the licence renewal fee for her motorcycle. Hiedeliza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials and tools for the maintenance of the motorcycle. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Hiedeliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials and tools for motorcycle maintenance.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorn N. is 54 years old and she lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sokun Nang, are farmers who own a 2.2-hectare plot of land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. Now they have a problem because it is time to do farming but they do not have enough money. 

To improve production, Mrs. Thorn N. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, pesticide, and gasoline. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a teacher, while the others are attending a local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: John

texts.en:
44-year-old John R. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is married and has two children. His older child is now aged twenty. John's business is rice farming. He tills his own land where he plants and harvests rice crops. He also owns a sari-sari store that his wife runs. He has been farming for eleven years now and hopes to have a stable income for his family.

John joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. John has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. John is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and piglets. This will be the third loan taken out by John from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and piglets

loans.name: Suk

texts.en: Mrs. Suk H. has spent her life cultivating crops. She has a lot of experience in this sector; it's a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. She is now married and has four children. Three are also married and have already started new homes, while another is single. Her husband frequently works in the farm fields alongside her. The current family income from farming is insufficiently to serve them. Actually, Suk H. has been planning to earn extra revenue through investing in a new trade but she doesn’t have capital to begin the process. Thus, Suk H. decided to ask for a US $700 loan from Kiva’s project partner, HKL. She will invest this money to provide a small loan for monthly interests to people who are garment laborers. The loan will allow her to improve her profits.

loans.use: To provide a small loan for monthly interests.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 45 years old. Josephine is married to Romeo L. and has 6 children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

In 2007, Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She also plans to buy piglets that she can raise. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Josephine from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and piglets

loans.name: Nora's Group

texts.en:
Nora J. is from the village of Marapong, Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 57 years old. Nora is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are each collectively responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults.

Nora is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Nora owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector in rice production. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling of her own harvested rice. Nora has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Nora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Nora is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Nora from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living situation of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business

loans.name: Seun

texts.en:
Mrs. Seun N. is a married woman with three children, one of whom is a laborer in Thailand, while the others are attending local public school. Her husband, Mr. Sorn Khen, is a fisherman who can earn some money from selling fish and frogs to support his family. This family lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. 

Mrs. Seun N. is a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice to sell to support her family. Now she has a problem because her field should be planted but she does not have enough money to support it. So to improve production, Mrs. Seun N. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rent a plow to plow her field. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, gasoline, and rent a plow to plow her field

loans.name: Phally

texts.en: Mrs. Phally K. and her family live in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province. She is 45 years old. She is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where she can cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, it has a lot of insects, and it is far away from the irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Phally K. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline. Her husband, Mr. Phorlla Gnet, is a fisherman and a farming laborer, too. She is a mother of four children of whom all are attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: Wazeeran's Group

texts.en:
Wazeeran lives in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan, with her family of six members. Her husband has a business selling paint while one son is a bus conductor and another does embroidery and has a shop in the market. Wazeeran is a housewife and takes care of her two little daughters who are getting their education. 

Earlier she helped her son in establishing his embroidery business by receiving a loan from Asasah; this time she wants to help her husband who will buy paint for his business and meet the orders of his customers. 

Wazeeran is hopeful that her husband’s business will be in a better position after making this investment and she will be able to help her daughters in finishing their education.

loans.use: Purchase paint tins for resale

loans.name: Bin

texts.en:
Mrs. Bin C. is a 47-year-old cake seller. She usually makes the cakes at home and then walks around her community to sell them, generating approximately $5 per day.

Bin C. has another income earner in her husband, who drives a motorcycle taxi. The couple has two children who attend the local public school. The family’s current income is not adequate to serve them.

Bin C. wants to pursue additional revenue by raising poultry but she has no capital to begin this process. Bin C. is therefore requesting a loan to purchase small poultry to raise in the stall she built.

loans.use: To purchase poultry to raise.

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
Mrs. Son O. lives in Trapeang Krasang village in Takeo province. She was born in 1976. She is a mother of three children -- two are in local public school and the third is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Son O. is a farmer who owns two hectares of land where she cultivates rice to sell and support her family. Her husband, Mr. Thou Khun, is a motorbike taxi driver. In order to improve their family’s standard of living, they want to start breeding animals but they do not have enough money.

To achieve this goal Mrs. Son O. is asking for a loan to buy a cow, two pigs for breeding, and pig food. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow, two pigs for breeding, and pig food.

loans.name: Akbar's Group

texts.en:
Akbar is a resident of  Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan. She has two sons; one of them is getting his education while the other helps his father in his snack-selling business. 

Akbar’s family is very poor and her husband and son work very hard to support their family. They go to different areas of the city all the day to sell their snacks and make an income which, however, is insufficient for the whole family. 

Akbar has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who will buy the snacks in bulk to increase his sales. She is hopeful that this investment will make her family’s life easier by increasing her household income.

Akbar also operates a little sewing business to help her family financially.

loans.use: Purchase snacks wholesale for resale

loans.name: Noeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noeun N. is a widow with three children who attend local public school. The family lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She was born in 1968 and she is a farmer who owns 2.3 hectare of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. She is also a farm laborer.

Now she has some problems because her field is ready to grow rice but she did not have enough money for supplies. To improve her production Mrs. Noeun N. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline.

loans.name: 06.03.03-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa Group

texts.en:
Toán Lê Thị  (34) is a 43-year-old woman living in the town of Hoằng Hóa-Thanh Hóa.  Toán is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 06.03.03-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa (06.03.03-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa).

Toán is married and has 3 adult children.  To making a living, Toán operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale.  Toán has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2003, Toán joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Toán has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Toán plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  L. Thị Sáu (33) is a 50-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  N. Thị Gái (5) is a 43-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Toán Lê Thị  (34) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoằng Hóa-Thanh Hóa.  Toán là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 06.03.03-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa (06.03.03-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gà để bán.  Toán thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Toán kiếm được khoảng 1,500,000 VND.  Vào 2003, Toán đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Toán đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. Thị Sáu (33) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  N. Thị Gái (5) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok N. is villager in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province and she is 53 years old. She has three children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is employed in a private company, and the other attends local public school

Mrs. Sok N. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Rum Yorn, is a fisherman who can earn some money from selling fish.

They try to work hard but they earn little income. So, to improve her family’s living conditions Mrs. Sok N. is asking for a loan to buy agricultural machinery. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy agricultural machinery.

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Mrs. Sem S. lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province and she is 61 years old. She is a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Now her problem is that her field is infertile soil.

So to improve production, Mrs. Sem S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer.

Her husband, Mr. Nem Morm, is a village chief who gets a low salary to support his family. She is a mother of two children, one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other attends local public school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Fouzia's Group

texts.en:
Fouzia is the wife of M. A. and has three children; two of them are getting their education and one is not of school-going age yet. She lives in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan, with her family. Her husband is a painter; he paints buildings, houses etc. to earn income for his family. 

These days her husband needs money to buy tins of paints to meet the orders of his customers. Therefore, Fouzia has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her husband's business. The amount will help him to buy the paint in bulk and to meet the orders of his customers. 

Fouzia is also a very hard-working lady. She operates her business of sewing clothes. She does this work to share the financial burden with her husband. 
Fouzia is hopeful that after the investment, her husband will never lose his business, because he will have paint in bulk to fill the orders.

loans.use: Purchase paint to meet his clients' orders

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom T. is a villager in Phngeas village in Takeo province and she is 29 years old. She owns a general store at her home where she can earn some money from selling groceries to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Sroeurn Hem, is a farmer who owns a three-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Now she has a problem because her husband’s field is far away from any irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Mom T. is applying for a loan to dig a well and with the rest of the loan she will buy fertilizer, gasoline, and a motor.

She is a mother of two children who all attend the local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To dig a well.

loans.name: Moul

texts.en:
Mrs. Moul R. has spent her life cultivating crops. She has a lot of experience in this, having learned fR. her grandparents when she was young. She was married, but divorced her husband, and she has four children. Two of her daughters are employed in the garment factory and provide their little income to help with family expenses.

Recently, Moul R. wants to invest in a new business line of selling various foods for the purpose of earning extra profit for her family. Because she has no capital, Moul R. is seeking a loan to begin this business. With any remaining money fR. the loan, she will plant crops during this coming rainfall season.

loans.use: To begin selling various foods and to plant crops.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom S. lives in Phngeas village in Takeo province and she is 24 years old. She is the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Chan Oun, is shown in the photo with her.

Mrs. Mom S. is a pig breeder who is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband is a farmer who owns a small piece of the land he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family; he is a fisherman, too.

Mrs. Mom S.’s problem is that her husband’s field has infertile soil, it is far away from irrigation system, and it has a lot of insects. So, to improve production, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, gasoline, and pesticide.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Paterna

texts.en:
Paterna M. is from the village of Capayangan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 60 years old. Paterna is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Paterna owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling soft drinks and other beverages in the local community. Paterna has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Paterna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Paterna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to  purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Paterna is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Paterna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her store. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna N. is a villager in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province and she was born in 1983. She is a mother of a child who is enrolled in the local public school. Her husband, Mr. Kumphas You, is a teacher at the local school. He is shown in the photo with her.

Mrs. Vanna N. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare (5-acre) plot of land she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She is a pig breeder, too.

Since her pig-breeding is going well she wants to expand it. So, to improve her pig-breeding, Mrs. Vanna N. is applying for a loan to buy pig feed and pig vaccine.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and pig vaccine

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthorn C. lives in Pou Ta Mok village in Takeo province and she was born in 1980. She is the mother of two children who are both attending the local public school. Her husband, Mr. Khum Tub, is an agricultural machinery driver. He is shown in the photo with her.

Mrs. Chanthorn C. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare (5-acre) plot of land she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support their family living.

Now Mrs. Chanthorn C. has some problems because her field has infertile soil, it has a lot of insects, and it is far away from the irrigation system. So, to improve production, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie L. is from the village of Capayangan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 37 years old. Josie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Josie owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Josie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Josie is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Josie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Kheng C. is 53 years old and she lives in Pou Ta Mok village in Takeo province. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local public school, another one is helping her to farm, and the other one sells groceries. Her husband, Mr. Gnem Sor, is a pig breeder who is able to earn some money from selling pigs to support his family. He is shown in the photo with her.

Mrs. Kheng C. is a farmer who owns two hectares (5 acres) of land where she grows a crop to sell to support her family.

Now Mrs. Kheng C. has a problem because her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan she will buy gasoline and pesticide.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: 06.02.01-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa Group

texts.en:
Hoa C. Thị (6) is a 46-year-old woman living in the town of Hoằng Hóa-Thanh Hóa.  Hoa is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 06.02.01-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa (06.02.01-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa).


Hoa is married and has 2 adult children.  To making a living, Hoa operates a family member's business venture: a specialized retail store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling flowers in the local community.  Hoa has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 1,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2005, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Hoa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Hoa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. Thị Lương (8) is a 36-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  Lê Thị Hồng (57) is a 37-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


3.  H. Thị Nương (37) is a 35-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


4.  Lê Thị Thi (35) is a 38-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Hoa C. Thị (6) là 46 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoằng Hóa-Thanh Hóa.  Hoa là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 06.02.01-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa (06.02.01-Hoằng Châu-Hoằng Hóa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán hoa trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Hoa thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hoa kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2005, Hoa đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hoa đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. Thị Lương (8) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Lê Thị Hồng (57) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  H. Thị Nương (37) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Lê Thị Thi (35) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chan Thoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan Thoeun L. is a villager in Chong Angkar village in Takeo province and she was born in 1983. She is a weaver at her home from which she is able to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Seourn Sem, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Now Mrs. Chan Thoeun L. has a problem because her husband’s field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan she will buy gasoline and pesticide.

Mrs. Chan Thoeun L. is the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local public school, while the other is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita C. is from the village of Capayangan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 25 years old. Lolita is married and has 3 very young children. To make a living, Lolita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Lolita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Lolita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Lolita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing seeds for farming

loans.name: Len

texts.en:
Producing Khmer noodles is part of 41-year-old Len S.’s daily routine. It is one snack food that is a necessary, vital product to people. She learned to do this from her grandmother and she is very widely known in this sector since before she was married. Her husband is skilled in making wooden furniture by hand in the village. 

Len S. has four children who live together in the family home. Recently, one of her daughters is ready to be married and she wants to have her own house to live independently. Because of this reason, Len S. has requested a loan to add to her personal money in order to start building a new house.

loans.use: To start building a new house

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a single mother of two children, aged 10 and 6 years. She is the head of her family with the responsibility of the family welfare resting entirely on her. 

Juliet lives in Fort Portal, Uganda in a rented home and operates a clothing shop, a business she has been into for the last 10 years, having started in a very small kiosk then moved to a container. She has been progressing and now she has her shop in more permanent structures along one of the up and coming streets of the town. 

Juliet confides that theft, high rent, and the ever increasing taxes are her major challenges in her clothing business. She would like to transform her shop into a very big one and even have branches around town and in other neighboring towns. She intends to use the loan funds to purchase clothes in cartons, rolls, or boxes for selling in her shop.

loans.use: purchasing clothes in cartons, rolls, or boxes for resale

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle C. is from the village of Carugmanan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 48 years old. Annabelle is married and has school-aged children. To make a living, Annabelle owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Annabelle has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Annabelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annabelle has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Annabelle is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Annabelle from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty I. is from the village of Western Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 52 years old. Betty is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Betty owns & operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Betty has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Betty joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as cloth, needles & thread. Betty is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Betty from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Martha's Group

texts.en:
Martha lives in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan.  She does not have any children. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the market. He selected this business because he has ten years of sales experience in a grocery store.  

Martha is a very supportive lady. She runs a domestic-sewing business. She does this work to help her husband financially. 

Martha is a regular client of Asasah. She has successfully completed four loans and now she has applied for a loan for the fifth time from Asasah. She will invest the loan amount in her husband’s business. The loan amount will help him to buy groceries in bulk for his grocery shop.  

Martha is hopeful that this investment will put her husband’s business into a better position which will result in an increase in his income.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing tomato seeds

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn B. is from the village of Katutungan, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 33 years old. Jocelyn is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. She also retails coffee and sugar. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase inventory and as working capital. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul S. is from the village of Malintubuan, Labason, Zamboanga Del Norte. He is 46 years old. Paul is married. To make a living, Paul operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Paul has been engaged in his business for more than eight years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2009, Paul joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Paul has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Paul is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Paul from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About PMPC Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen lives with her family in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan. She has two children who are getting their education. Her husband has a timber selling business. He purchases timbers from the market and then sells them at a good profit. 

A caring lady, Parveen stays at home taking care of her children and carrying out her responsibilities as a housewife. She has applied for a loan for the fifth time from Asasah to improve the business of her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy timbers in bulk which will minimize his cost of purchase.
 
Parveen hopes that by making an investment in her husband’s business, it will improve with the passage of time and one day her family will be able to overcome its financial problems.

loans.use: Purchase timbers for resale

loans.name: Rosefina

texts.en:
Rosefina D. is from the village of Upper Dicayas. She is 47 years old. Rosefina is married and has two adult and one school-aged children. Rosefina owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling bag & shoe products in the local community. Rosefina is just starting this business.

In 2007, Rosefina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from PMPC, which was for 14,900 Philippine pesos (PHP) and was used to purchase additional inventory & as working capital.

Rosefina is now requesting her fifth loan from PMPC, for 14,900 PHP, which will be used as additional capital for her bag and shoe business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for her ukay-ukay business

loans.name: Pableo' Group

texts.en:
Angielita P. is from the village of Villaramos, Manukan, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old. Angielita is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is P.'s Group.

Angielita is married and has three adult children. Angielita owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Angielita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns an average of approximately 1,500 Philippine pesos (PHP)  a month from it.

In 2010, Angielita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Angielita is requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for hog raising. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Angielita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: additional capital for hog raising

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 40-year-old man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. His wife is a subsistence farmer, meaning Charles is charged with the responsibility of looking after the family in terms of the other family requirements. 

Charles runs a retail shop which has been operational for the last six years. From the profit from the shop, Charles has been able to construct a small commercial house and also keep his family afloat. Charles would like to transform his retail shop into a wholesale business like many of his colleagues in the sector of retailing. 

This is his fifth loan from HOFOKAM and he is to use the loan funds to buy sugar, salt, soap, and other domestic items to sell in his shop.

loans.use: buying sugar, soap, and domestic items for resale

loans.name: Jerimina

texts.en:
58-year-old K. Jerimina is a happy-go-lucky and down-to-earth married mother of four kids. She is widowed but she has ably carried on her shoulders the responsibility and burden of being the family’s breadwinner with enough courage and conviction, ever since her husband passed on.

This is all down to the hard work Jerimina has brought to bear in her banana plantation farming business. This banana farming and selling business has been her family’s recourse for the last fifteen years and, with it, she has given her children a worthwhile education.

Jerimina’s profits per month are in the range of 180,000 to 200,000 shillings, depending on the season. She was at first a retailer but quit. With this loan, she is hoping to revamp her banana plantation with purchased fertilizer and manure that she hopes will improve her yield and, in the course of time, her income.

loans.use: To purchase high-grade fertilizer and manure for her banana gardens

loans.name: Xynthia

texts.en:
Xynthia E. is from the village of Langcataon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Xynthia is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Xynthia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Xynthia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Xynthia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Xynthia is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Xynthia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Shareefan's Group

texts.en:
Shareefan is Christian by religion. She comes from Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan. She lives with her husband who is a government employee and is a mother of six children. Five of them are getting their education while the sixth one runs a timber-selling business. 

A very talented lady, Shareefan supports her family by making and selling artificial flowers. Her daughters also help her in her business. Her son has been involved in his timbers-selling business for over five years. He sells the timbers in the community. He does this work to support his family financially. He had to quit his studies but he doesn’t want his siblings to have to quit their studies due to financial reasons. Therefore, he started this business.
  
Shareefan has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her son's business. He will buy the timbers in bulk which will help him in fulfilling larger orders on time. 

Shareefan is hopeful that this investment will make a positive impact on her son’s business and he will be able to increase his income in a result.

loans.use: Purchase timbers in bulk for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buying seeds of vegetables for farming

loans.name: Pech

texts.en:
Pech P., 32 years old, owns a small wooden house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, and gasoline. Pech P. retails her inventory to people who are passers-by and are also her neighbors living near her house. She has been running a grocery investment for a long time and earns an average of $2 a day. To ensure the entire family has financial stability, her husband works in construction. This couple now lives with three children who are going to school or to work. 

Beside their current businesses, Pech P. and her husband wish to fish around the river in order to raise additional income for their family but this action requires many tools. Because she has no money, Pech P. has asked for a loan to buy a boat, nets, and traps to begin fishing.

loans.use: To buy a boat, nets, and traps to begin fishing.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
Mercedita O. is from the village of Talon, Gingoog City. She is 42 years old. Mercedita is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Mercedita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Mercedita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mercedita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercedita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Mercedita is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Mercedita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nasreen Begum's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen begum lives in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan, with her family. Her husband does labor in order to make a living for his family. She doesn't have any children, so in order to pass her time, she started her beauty salon a few years ago on receiving a loan from Asasah. The beauty salon is doing well. She enjoys her work. 

Nasreen has a good reputation among her customers and would like to be able to increase her customers as well.  She wants to expand her business, for which reason, she has applied for a loan. With the loan amount, she will buy more beauty materials such as cosmetics and creams. She will also hire a worker who will assist her in her work.

Nasreen is hopeful that her business will improve  and make her more profit. 

Note: Parveen, a group member of Nasreen's, is demonstrating her clothes business in this photo.

loans.use: Purchase beauty materials for beauty salon

loans.name: Mornica

texts.en:
Mornica A. N. is fifty-one years old, married, and has five children, aged between twenty-four years old and thirteen years old. Her business is located at Kibuye in Kisumu, Kenya. She has been selling such items as detergents, soft drinks, flour, cooking oil and others for the last two years to the local people. 

Mornica says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is that there are so many people doing the same kind of business as hers in the area and so customers are spoilt for choice. However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She describes herself as God-fearing and honest.

loans.use: buying soft drinks

loans.name: Jelcome

texts.en:
48-year-old B. Jelcome has banked on finances from his audio music-sales shop to cater for his family of four for the last fifteen years in Kinyansano Village, Rukungiri. He has made profitable use of his idea that no one else was running this kind of business in his part of the country. In a month, he makes profits totalling 200,000 shillings.

This former teacher has no regrets over his decision to quit his profession. He reasons that he is now able to make more money than when he was a teacher, but he says he has had to summon up a lot of hard work and determination to be where he is. First he says he had to fight off detractors who were bent on seeing his business go up in smoke.

By virtue of the fact that he sells all genres of music, Jelcome has established for himself a big niche, as many people with different tastes of music patronize his place of work. With this loan, he is reckoning on buying more copies of original music discs and tapes to resell to his increasing clientele.

loans.use: To buy more copies of original music discs and tapes to sell

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun C., who was born in 1968, lives in Pump Edth village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Ngory Brus, is a bed maker who supports his family with the money he earns from selling beds. Since her husband’s business is going well, Mrs. Thoeun C. wants to expand it. She is asking for a loan to buy timber stock to cut trees for firewood and also to buy palm trees. She is the mother of two children: one helps her husband make beds and the other attends the local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy timber stock

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura E. is from the village of  Gingoog City. She is 40 years old. Laura is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Laura owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Laura has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Laura joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laura has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Laura is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Laura from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita T. is from the town of Poblacion, Kadingilan Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Elenita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Elenita owns & operates an appliance repair shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing repair services to local community members. Elenita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Elenita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase repair equipment to improve the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Elenita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase repair equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani has applied for loan from Asasah to repair her son’s rickshaw. She lives with her family in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan, where her son is a rickshaw driver. He has been in this work for the last six years. He learnt this driving skill from his father. He got his education till 8th standard and couldn’t study further because his father had no financial resources besides his meager income.  

Rani started making artificial flowers a few years ago to support her family financially. She sells her flowers to gift shops and in the community as well and generates income for the family. She is very good at her art and gets regular orders. Rani will use the loan amount for repairing her son’s rickshaw. 

A newly maintained rickshaw will run more smoothly and help her son to work for longer hours thus making him more money.

loans.use: Repair her son's rickshaw

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhom U., 46, is a villager in Pump Edth village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Seng Sok, is a construction worker who earns a little money to support his family. Although they work a lot, they earn a small income. To improve this condition, Mrs. Sokhom U. is applying for a loan to buy two piglets and pig food for breeding. She is the mother of three children: two are construction workers and one attends the local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy two piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Maribel Zumel Group

texts.en:
Maribel Z. is from the village of Dolores, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Maribel is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Maribel Z. Group.

Maribel is married and has 3 school-aged children. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Maribel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Maribel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long S., 59 years old, is a rice and vegetable grower from Phnom Penh, the capital. She runs her business on her own farmland where she grows different kinds of crops like cabbages, rice, potatoes, and morning glories, which she sells to a buyer when they have matured. She currently earns an average of US$1.50 a day and has been running the business for years. 

Long S. is a widowed mother blessed with five children. Three of them are now married and other two are single, and they all are employed at different jobs. Long S. is taking out her first loan to purchase an old motorbike to provide transportation for her family.

loans.use: To purchase an old motorbike.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine P. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting rice and corn for sale. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 28 years now.

Josephine joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers. This will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Josyline

texts.en:
30-year-old N. Josyline began her retail shop over eight years ago in Bwambari, Rukungiri, with the sole objective of extricating her family from the harsh, narrow circumstances that they found themselves in. She was, prior to that, a married housewife who relied on handouts from her husband who, in a sense, was not doing great in his business undertakings.

Josyline had to set her wits to work. This meant she had to conjure up some business of her own to help her husband to support their family of four people.

What Josyline anticipated at the threshold of her business has not happened; she thought her chances of success were minimal. With her strong resolve and a sense of determination, she has opened new horizons for herself and her family. Per month, her business generates her profits that amount to 360,000 shillings. Her good customer relationship skills are also worth mentioning. 

With this loan, Josyline wants to make purchases to restock her retail shop with goods such as sorghum, rice, groundnuts (peanuts) and sugar.

loans.use: To purchase in bulk retail items like rice, groundnuts and sugar

loans.name: Shah Sultan

texts.en:
Shah Sultan is a daughter of M. K.. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with 6 children. Her husband has got a general store where she works to help support the family.

She needs to take out a loan for her husband to purchase essential things such as, beverages, canned food and so on. Her husband hopes to have a great number of clients and to progress more.

loans.use: purchasing beverages and food

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica D. is from the village of Miaray, Dangcagan Bukidnon. She is 57 years old. Veronica is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Veronica owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Veronica has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Veronica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Veronica has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Veronica is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Veronica from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community.
