loans.name: Sothy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sothy H. is married, with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. She is 40 years old. She and her family are living in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She is a Khmer noodle seller in their local village and can earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Chab Choem, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where he can cultivate rice to sell to support his family. 

Now she has a problem because her husband’s field is infertile. So to improve production, Mrs. Sothy H. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, a plow to plow her husband’s field, and, with the rest of the loan, a cow for breeding. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a plow  to plow her husband’s field

loans.name: Leonie

texts.en:
Leonie A. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Leonie is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Leonie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Leonie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

Leonie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonie is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Leonie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: La

texts.en:
Mrs. La K. and her family live in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She was born in 1961. She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to grow crops on to sell to support her family. 

Now her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. La K. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, a cow for breeding, rent a plow to plow her field, and, with the rest of the loan, she plans to buy some piglets and pig feed. Her husband, Mr. Met Chea, is a construction worker. With these activities, they support a child who is a soldier. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, a cow for breeding, and rent a plow to plow her field

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda M. is from the village of Cotta, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years old. Imelda is married and has nine adult children. To make a living, Imelda owns and operates an eatery business. She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

 In 2009, she joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her eatery. Imelda is now requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used for additional capital for her eatery. This will be the 3rd  loan taken out by Imelda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her eatery

loans.name: Chroek

texts.en:
S. was born in 1973.  She is a married woman blessed with two children. One of her children is no longer in school but the other one is a student. Her husband's name is Phon, 39 years-old and he is on the left of the photo.  Phon works planting vegetable crops. 

To earn a living, S. has built a pigpen behind her house where she raises many pigs. Because the pig-raising business is a very profitable one for S. and her family, S. has requested a loan to buy additional feed and piglets to raise for sale during the period when pork commands the highest price.

loans.use: To buy additional feed and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Ren

texts.en:
Mrs. Ren K. is a villager in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She is 47 years old. She is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Rorn Tom, is a palm juice collector who can earn a little money from selling palm sugar to support his family. 

Although they try to work hard, they can earn only a little income. So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Ren K. is asking for a loan to buy three piglets and pig feed for breeding, and with the rest of the loan, she plans to buy a cow and fertilizer to do farming. She is a mother of six children, three of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are attending local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy three piglets, pig feed for breeding, etc.

loans.name: Levi

texts.en:
52-year-old Levi J. is from the town of Banga. He is married and has 4 children. He still has children who go to school and he dreams for them to finish college and have a bright future. To make a living, Levi owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Levi has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

Levi joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Levi is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Levi from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn Q. is from Bernad Subdivision, Aguada, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 43 years of age. Jocelyn is married and has 2 children both of whom are now school-aged. To make a living, Jocelyn is engage in operating a sari-sari (variety) store and retailing Hypochlorine, a disinfectant and anti-stain chemical. Her main source of income comes from her sari-sari store and hypo-retailing business. Jocelyn has been engaged in  this kind of business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

 In August 2008, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Jocelyn is now requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used as added capital for her sari-sari store and hypo-retailing businesses. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store and Hypo-retailing businesses

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Yolanda S. is from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old. Yolanda is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Yolanda owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing hairdressing and beauty services to local community members. Yolanda has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Yolanda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yolanda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Yolanda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the second loan taken out by Yolanda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou A. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 36 years old, married to Alfredo, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou plants and harvests rice to sell. She has been engaged in her business for more than a few years now.

In 2007, Marilou joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her 6th loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam O. is living in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province and she was born in 1982. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. Now she has a problem because her field has infertile soil and she wants to start a new business, but she does not have enough money. 

So to improve production, Mrs. Sam O. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, rice seed, and with the rest of the loan, she plans to buy some piglets and pig feed for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Nem Ben, is a laborer. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending local public school, while the other is too small to work or study. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, rice seed, etc.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy G. is from the town of Banga. She is 36 years old and is involved in farming. She plants rice crops and sells her harvest at her town's local market. She also manages a sari-sari (variety) store located at her house. She has been engaged in her business for more than five years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

Nancy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya lives in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan. She has five children. Three of them are getting their education while the other two work at their jobs to help financially support the family. Her husband is a street-hawker and sells snacks from a four-wheeled cart. 

Surriya is a very talented lady. She does embroidery work to supplement the family's income. She has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah, to help her husband to buy more snacks to improve his business. Suraiya is hopeful that her household income will be improved by making this investment in her husband’s business.

loans.use: Purchase snacks for reselling

loans.name: Minieta

texts.en:
Minieta P. is from P2-A Bañadero, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years of age. Minieta is married to Tomas P., a carpenter, and has no children. Mineita is engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store. Aside from that, she is also receiving support from her husband's work as a carpenter. Her main source of income comes from her sari-sari store business. Minieta has been engaged this business for one year already and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from this activity.

 In 2009, Minieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Minieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from PMPC. Minieta is now requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to add to her capital for her sari-sari store business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Minieta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Kheng R., 65, is an older woman and the widowed mother of three children. All three of them are single and are working in different fields. To earn a living, Kheng R. owns a small store where it is a good location to raise income. In her shop, she sells grocery items to people who live in the village. She has another financial earner in her son who is a bus driver in a small company. 

Additionally, the couple always takes time to cultivate a rice crop for the purpose of eating. Growing rice crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. There is a neighbor’s farmland in a good location for faming. Kheng R. wants to be the owner of this land but she lacks money to buy it. So, she is applying for a US$ 900 to purchase the piece of farmland, on which she will plant crops to generate extra income.

loans.use: To buy a piece of farmland.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhorn N., who was born in 1973, is a villager in Dak Por village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Bok Me, is a coconut seller who can earn some money to support his family. Although they work a lot, they can earn only a little money to support their family. 

So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Sokhorn N. is seeking a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is attending local public school, while another one is helping her do farming, and the other is only six years old. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Sem

texts.en:
Mrs. Sem P. lives in Kouk Kruos village in Takeo province and she is 47 years old. She is a congee seller in her local village and besides this, she is a farmer who owns a more than two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Cham Roeun Brang, is a mechanic. 

This couple work a lot but they can earn only a little income. So to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Sem P. is asking for a loan to buy an ox to plow her field. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a car driver who gets a low salary to support his family, while the other is attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy an ox to plow her field

loans.name: Katabushera Tukore Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
Over the last six years, to improve his family’s welfare, K. James has depended on his agricultural produce business and his side-business selling domestic animals in Kagashe, Rukungiri. At the young age of 28, he is a man with duties, being that his wife is a housewife and he has one child. He also has five dependents to cater for.

Before James even took thought of setting forth on this business, he was a builder who survived on peanuts. Builders are not highly paid in his part of the country. In a month, this cheerful hard working gentleman says he now makes close to 200,000 shillings.

With this loan, James wants to buy bags of the more lucrative coffee crop that he thinks will earn him more income. He thinks he has already laid a strong foundation for the future and, with this loan, he says his future business prospects are promising.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of the more lucrative coffee crop that he will later resell

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza R. is from the village of San  Pedro. She is 48 years old. Liza is married and has 3 children The eldest is an adult while  the remaining 2 are school-aged. To make a living, Liza owns & operates a business venture in the  Aqua-Culture sector, culturing oysters. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from oyster culture knows as "Talaba" in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP average a month for these activities.

In 2007, Liza joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials for oyster culture activities. Liza is requesting a new loan of 14,500 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Liza from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business of oyster culture

loans.name: Sokh

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokh P., 39, is a farmer living in a commune in Kompong Tom Province. She raises pigs and rice crops. She has a life partner in her husband who appears in the photo here. He is a palm climber and also fishes in and around the river. They have three children, two of whom are students and other one is still not enrolled school. 

Sokh P. planted rice crops a few months ago but her rice is not growing well and it may require fertilizer. To solve this problem, Sokh P. requests a loan to buy fertilizer to increase her crop yield.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to increase her crop yield.

loans.name: Yasmeen Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen akhtar’s husband has a timber shop in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan. She lives there with her family of four people, two children and herself with her husband. 

Both of her children are getting an education. Yasmeen akhtar wants them to finish their education for which she works very hard. She makes and sells artificial flowers to pay their school fees. 

Yasmeen’s husband wants to buy more timber for his shop because he has received big order to fill. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for that purpose. She hopes that fulfillment of this order will bring good profit to her husband.

loans.use: Purchase timbers for selling

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. She is 36 years old and married with four children between the ages of 12 and 19. Three of the children are currently attending school.

She has been practicing mixed farming for ten years and during that time has employed people on a temporary basis depending on the work load. Her main products are milk and eggs which she sells locally. She also relies on the income from her husband who is employed and farming on rented land to provide for the family's basic needs. Her biggest challenge has been the unfavorable market prices for her eggs.

Sarah has a good record with Juhudi Kilimo after successfully completing a previous loan of 30,000 KES. She has requested this loan of 40,000 KES to expand her poultry project. The proceeds from this loan will enable her to pay school fees for her children.

In the future, she hopes to have increased the number of her poultry and to be earning sufficient income.

She hopes that the loan amounts will be increased in the future.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project.

loans.name: Fely Fuentivilla's Group

texts.en:
Fely F. is from P4 Embargo, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years of age. She is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group member if someone is delinquent or default. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Fely F.'s Group'. 

Fely is married to Victor F., a carpenter and at the same time a farmer. They were blessed with 2 children; one is an adult and the other one is a teenager. Fely is engaged in operating a sari-sari (variety) store. Aside from that, the family has support from her husband from his wage as a carpenter and income from their corn production activity. Her main source of income comes from her sari-sari store business and she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from this activity. She’s been engaged in this kind of business for a year already.

 In April 2010, Fely joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. As a newly recognized member, she is now requesting a loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used to add to her capital for her sari-sari store business. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Fely from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store business

location.town: P4 Embargo, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Rorn K. lives in Roliek village in Takeo province and she is 46 years old. She is a farmer who owns a 2.5-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. Now she has a problem because her field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve production, Mrs. Rorn K. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and rent a plow to plow her field. 

Her husband, Mr. Hem Sun, is a traditional medicine seller who can earn some money to support his family. She is a mother of four children, three of whom are attending local public school, while the other one is helping her husband sell traditional medicine. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, etc.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 53 years old and married, with eight children between the ages of 15 and 32. Three of the children are currently attending school.

She is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. Beatrice has been farming for nine years and has employed two people from her community. Her products are milk, maize, beans, potatoes, peas and vegetables which she sells to the local market.

Her biggest challenges in this business are the marketing of milk and the fluctuation in the prices of milk.

Beatrice has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 66,600 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow and build a dairy unit. This loan will enable her to provide enough milk for her family and earn income that will enable her to meet the basic needs of the family. In the future, she would like to purchase more dairy cows to increase her milk production and also to venture into zero grazing.

She is grateful to Juhudi for empowering the poor.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and build a dairy unit.

loans.name: Halima's Group

texts.en:
Halima lives in Borewala, a city of shrines in Pakistan, where her husband sells crockery to earn income for his family. Her family has been settled in Borewala for over twenty-five years. 

Halima knits clothes by taking orders from her neighborhood to help her husband in bearing the financial burden of the family. She is the mother of four sons and two daughters. One of her sons is employed in a shoe-selling business while the other sells the crockery like his father. Her other children are getting their education. 

Last year Halima helped her son get started in his crockery business by receiving a loan from Asasah. This time she has applied for a loan because her son wants to buy more crockery such as glass dinner sets, tea sets, and so on for his business.

loans.use: Purchase crockery for reselling

loans.name: Virginia Marilyn

texts.en:
Virginia Marilyn G. is from the village of Daanglungsod, Katipunan. She is 56 years old. Virginia Marilyn is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Virginia Marilyn owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Virginia Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Virginia Marilyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & to provide working capital. Virginia Marilyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory for her sari-sari (variety) store. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Virginia Marilyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Chhoeung

texts.en: Mrs. T. is a 49-year-old widow and is the mother of five children. Four of them are now married and live separately and the other one is single. T. currently stays at home to sell a few produce items in her small store in front of her home. She sells such wares as cooking ingredients, cakes, and some vegetables to people in the village. In order to earn additional income and to make her business more successful, T. is applying for a loan to add to her working capital and increase her inventory.

loans.use: To add to her working capital and her inventory

loans.name: Seline

texts.en:
Seline A. O. is thirty-one years old. She is married and has six children between the ages of 12 and 1, for whom she hopes to provide quality education. 

She hawks secondhand clothes in Kisumu. She has been in this business for the last three years. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that during the rainy seasons she is not able to maximize sales as she moves from place to place. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more secondhand clothes to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to open her own boutique. She also hopes to achieve a clientele base of about one thousand people. She describes herself as hardworking and determined.

loans.use: Clothes

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine D. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and rice at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans, rice, etc. to sell.  Catherine is 29 years old and is married to a policeman. She has one child who does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up her store of goods.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock bags of beans, rice, etc. to sell

loans.name: Salvador

texts.en:
E. Salvador is from the village of Daanglungsod, Katipunan. She is 56 years old. E. is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, E. owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables, spices, & daily use products in the local community. E. has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, E. joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. E. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. E. is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 10th loan taken out by E. from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Jobielyn

texts.en:
Jobielyn D. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 22 years old. Jobielyn is single. To make a living, Jobielyn owns and operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling electronic prepaid cellphone loads in the local community. She is also engaged in a dealership of Natasha products like shoes, sandals and personal care products. Jobielyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jobielyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jobielyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jobielyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jobielyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Gelevazio

texts.en:
For over a decade, 43-year-old K. Gelevazio has been depending on his banana plantation in Kabwoma village, Rukungiri, to earn him income. This has been his major source of livelihood though he has also been making a side-income working as a security guard in Rukungiri Town.

By Gelevazio’s own admission, it’s his devotion, hard work and determination which has been his requisite stock in trade. He is an optimist who believes his prospects for the future for his family and his businesses are up to the mark.

Gelevazio is happily married with six children, all going to school. He took over this business from his late father. In a month, he makes profits that sum up to 150,000 shillings.

With this loan, Gelevazio is looking at rejuvenating his banana farm. He wants to buy more banana stems to plant on a larger scale.

loans.use: To purchase more banana stems to plant on a large scale

loans.name: Samoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Samoeun S. is a villager in Pou Ta Mok village in Takeo province. She is 37 years old. She owns a general store at her home so that she can earn some money to support her family by selling groceries. Her husband, Mr. Phorn Hem, is a farmer who owns 1.5 hectares of land, where he cultivates rice to sell to support his family. He is also a laborer. Now she has a problem because the soil in her husband’s field is infertile and has a lot of insects. To improve production, Mrs. Samoeun S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline. With the rest of the loan she intends to buy more groceries to resell. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is helping her husband with the farming. The others are attending a local public school. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean C. is from the village of Port Area, Iligan City. She is 37 years old. Jean is widowed and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Jean owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products like chicken and pork barbecue in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Jean joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jean is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP to use for the same purpose. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Jean from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Adiba Siddique's Group

texts.en:
Adiba siddique has been living in Borewala, city of shrines, in Pakistan for the last 16 years with her husband and four children, who are all getting their education. Her husband is a motor mechanic, while Adiba sews clothes for her neighborhood clients in order to support her husband financially. Adiba’s husband runs a motor workshop in the market where he can repair every kind of vehicle. He started learning this art at a young age, and now he is an expert at it.
 
Adiba has applied for a loan from Asasah to invest the loan amount in her husband’s workshop. The amount will help him buy new repair tools for his workshop. She is hopeful that the investment in her husband’s business will make it more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase repair tools for her husband's motor workshop

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She sells fruit and makes an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a police officer who also earns an income of USD 5 per day. Seang is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more fruit to expand her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to expand the business

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice D is currently in the business of selling dried fish, tomatoes and onions, and is requesting a loan to stock more dried fish to sell. Joice is 47 years old and is married with a husband who is a police officer. She has five children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Kha

texts.en: Mrs. Kha S. is a young woman and the mother of two small children. One is enrolled in school, and the other one is not yet attending school. She distills white wine to sell. Additionally, she uses the leftovers from distilling to feed a few pigs. She has another great earner in her husband, who sells ice cream. He also buys chopped wood in bulk to resell for a profit. In addition to their current jobs, the couple takes time to cultivate a rice crop when the farming season comes. Kha S. is lacking some supplies to use on her field and is asking for a Kiva loan. She will use the loan to pay for the fee of plowing farmland and to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, and seed to plant.

loans.use: To pay for plowing farmland and to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, and seed

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap B., who lives in Daeum Pou village in Takeo province, is 29 years old. She is a farmer who owns 2.2 hectares of land, where she cultivates rice to sell in order to support her family. Now she has a problem because the soil in her field is infertile and has a lot of insects. To improve production, Mrs. Pheap B. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline. Her husband, Mr. Thea Seng, owns agricultural machinery and is a fisherman. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is studying in a local public school. The youngest is one year old. Her husband is shown in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and gasoline

loans.name: Tem

texts.en: Tem S., 53, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. grows rice and raises pigs for an income of US $1.80 per day. Her husband is a farmer and palm juice seller, earning an income of about US $1 per day to help cover the family expenses. S. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy cows to help plow the rice field

loans.name: Zandra

texts.en:
Zandra L. is from the village of Port Area, Iligan City. She is 20 years old, single and has 1 very young child. Zandra owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily specialty products like chicken barbecue, in the local community. Zandra has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2008, Zandra joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Zandra is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Zandra from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lunh

texts.en: Lunh S., 38, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. S. is a farmer and grows rice for an income of US $3 per day. When she is not working in the field, she produces roofs made from palm leaves. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about US $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. S. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase a generator to recharge batteries for people in the village. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: to buy a generator to recharge batteries

loans.name: Panh

texts.en:
Panh S., 43, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. grows rice and watermelons for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman, earning an income of about USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a shop at the market to sell clothes and shoes. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is S.'s first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a shop at the market to sell clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A is currently in the business of selling beans, rice and maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of maize to sell. Mary is 45 years old and married; her husband is a laborer. She has 4 children and they all attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of maize to sell

loans.name: Husna's Group

texts.en:
Husna has lived with her family in Borewala, a city of shrines, for the past twenty years. Her husband is a goldsmith and runs a shop in the market where he sells gold jewelry. Husna helps her family financially by doing domestic sewing. She receives orders from her neighborhood clients and generates money by fulfilling them.

Husna has four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of them are getting their education while the oldest son is also a goldsmith. Husna is a very kind and supportive woman by nature. She enjoys her sewing business and the income from it encourages her to earn more for her family. She has applied for a loan from Asasah to purchase an electric sewing machine for her business. This will help her to sew more clothes in time.

loans.use: to purchase an electric sewing machine

loans.name: Yung

texts.en: Yung L., 38, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. L. sells coffee and sugar cane juice for an income of US $6 per day. Her husband is a blacksmith, earning an income of about US $5 per day to help cover the family expenses. L. is requesting a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: An

texts.en: Mrs. An A., 41, lives in Chambak village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder, selling pigs to help support her family. Her husband, Mr. Phen Mong, is a farmer who owns a two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support the family. They face a problem because Mr. Phen Mong’s field is infertile and is far from the irrigation system. To improve production, Mrs. An A. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide and to rent a plowing machine to plow the field. Mrs. An A. is the mother of three children: one is a clothes seller and the others are studying at the local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline and pesticide and to rent a plowing machine

loans.name: Eam

texts.en:
Eam C., 40, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. C. and her husband are farmers growing rice, earning an income of about $2.50 each per day to help cover the family expenses. 

C. is requesting a loan of $500 to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to purchase more plots of farmland to grow more rice.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: repair house

loans.name: Jakielou

texts.en:
Jakielou A. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Jakielou is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Jakielou runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Jakielou has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $180 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jakielou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jakielou is requesting a  oan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

She owns two hectares of land where she and her husband plant and harvest rice crops. They also help each other sell their harvest at the market. She also raises hogs and hopes to acquire additional piglets.

She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure, and to buy feed for the pigs. This will be her 8th loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora K. is currently in the business of selling scholastic materials such as boxes of chalk, text books, exercise books, pens, etc. and is requesting a loan to stock more books and boxes of chalk to sell.  She is 34 years old and is married to a teacher. She has three children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Agé de 33 ans, Monsieur  Dramane Koné est marié et père de 3 enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants  dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  Dramane Koné, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,   s’initia depuis plus de trois ans à cette activité d’achat et de vente des bazins blancs, soude caustique, teintures, etc. Il mène son activité à Wayerma I en face de l’Agence Malienne pour la Presse et la Publicité (AMAP) de Sikasso, non loin de la prison centrale où il dispose d’une boutique. Monsieur Koné est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de deux ans. Il est à son troisième prêt individuel. Ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce nouveau prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 20 paquets de soude caustique, 17 pièces de bazins, 13 sacs de potasse, 15 boîtes de teinture de couleurs différentes, etc. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et les revendre à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes teinturières de  la ville de Sikasso et environs.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce présent prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane Koné is married and the father of 3 children. He lives with his wife and their children in a large traditional family in Wayerma I, one of the residential neighborhoods in Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After havng tried a variety of different activities without success, three years ago Mr. Koné started his business of buying and selling white damask fabric, caustic soda, dyes, etc. He carries out this activity at Wayerma I, across from the Malian Agency for Press and Advertising (AMAP) in Sikasso, not far from the central prison, where he has a shop. Mr. Koné is very much sought after by his customers because of the quality of his products. Mindful of meeting the needs of his ever growing number of customers, he joined micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso more than two years ago. He is on his third individual loan, his previous loans all having been properly repaid. This new loan will allow him to buy 20 packets of caustic soda, 17 pieces of damask, 13 bags of potash, 15 boxes of dye in different colors, etc. He gets his supplies in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and sells to a clientele made up mostly of women who dye fabric and who are from the town of Sikasso and the surrounding area. With this new loan he expects to make a monthly profit of 200,000 CFA francs which will mainly be used to contribute towards household expenses and pay interest on the loan, the rest being invested in his business.

Translated from French by Sarah Puchner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various articles

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 1 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 50 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations sont le riz, l’arachide (avec Fatoumata D.) et le petit mil. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne, les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Fatoumata compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 6 Hectares.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Fatoumata D. compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60.000FCFA par campagne.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi 1 portent toutes leur confiance pour le bon déroulement de la campagne hivernale.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 1 group are married women, on average 50 years old with four children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to undertake successfully their winter campaign activities. They speculate on rice, ground nuts (as with Fatoumata D.), and millet. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. With this new loan, Fatoumata intends to buy seedlings and fertiliser, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate six hectares (approx. 15 acres). Her crop is sold after harvest in Nangola and the adjoining area, and in the town of Dioïla, to both men and women customers. Fatoumata D. hopes to attain an average profit of 60,000 FCFA per campaign. The women from the Benkadi 1 group are all hopeful for the successful progress of this winter campaign.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: seedlings, fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en:
Rosalyn V. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 37 years old, married and has three school-age children. She is a farmer. She owns land that she and her husband till for planting rice crops. She sells their harvest at the market. When not busy with farming duties, she offers manicure services to her neighbors and other people in her community.

Rosalyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Rosalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She also plans to buy materials for her manicure business. This will be her eighth loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: C2150 Tuzamurane Group

texts.en:
Hirariya is 27 years old and married with four children who are 1, 3, 4 and 7 years old. Hirariya is the leader of a group called "Tuzamurane". This group is well known in the clothing business. This is their second successful year in the business and they work every day.

Hirariya and her team realized that the capital they had would not allow them to expand meaningfully. For that reason, they are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that they can purchase additional styles of clothing. With the additional styles, Hirariya and her team will earn more profit which in turn will allow each member of the team to save and improve on the living conditions of their own families.

loans.use: To buy different styles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 58 years old. Wilma has been married to Ubaldo for forty years and now has three children. Her oldest child is aged 36. To make a living, Wilma plants, harvests, and sells rice. 

In 2009, Wilma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This loan will be Wilma's third loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan S., 54, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She produces traditional cakes to sell for an income of US $3 per day. Her husband is a lock repairman and sews shoes, earning an income of about US $2.80 per day. S. is requesting a loan of US $600 to purchase more cake ingredients to produce more cakes for her customers. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to produce more cakes

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Bun N., 37, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She is a housewife and her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about US $2 per day. N. is requesting a loan of US $300 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to operate his business efficiently. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Mies

texts.en: Mies T., 48, is a rattan cupboard seller  (wife in photo).  He and his wife care for one child.  Two other children are now adults.  Since 2000, Mies and his wife have owned a small rattan cupboard business.  They order rattan items in bulk or braid it themselves and sell door-to-door across the province.  Mies sells his items at a reasonable prices.  In order to better satisfy the needs of the customers, Mies seeks a loan to stock more rattan to sell.

loans.use: Stock more rattan cupboards to sell.

loans.name: Tum

texts.en: Tum N., 49, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. N. and her husband sell firewood for an income of US $5 per day. N. is requesting a loan of US $750 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow rice. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to grow rice

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida S. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 40 years old, married and has six school-aged children. She grows pigs for a living. Her family also owns two hectares of rice field that her husband manages. They also have two carabaos (water buffalo) and a cow that help in their farming. She says that one of the reasons she and her husband work hard is for their children to have a proper education and finish their studies.

In 2007, Zenaida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & farm supplies. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Zenaida from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & farm supplies

loans.name: Benkadi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 2 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 44 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations sont le riz, l’arachide, le maïs et le petit mil. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Chitan Traoré compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 2 hectares. 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45000FCFA par campagne.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi 2 portent toute leur confiance pour le bon déroulement de la campagne hivernale avec l’aide de Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 2 group are married women, on average 44 years old with three children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to undertake successfully their winter campaign activities. They speculate on rice, ground nuts, corn and millet. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. With this new loan, Chitan Traoré intends to buy seedlings and fertiliser, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate two hectares (approx. 5 acres). Her crop is sold after harvesting in Nangola and the adjoining area, and in the town of Dioïla, to both men and women customers. They hope to attain an average profit of 45,000 FCFA per campaign. The women from the Benkadi 2 group put their trust in a successful progress of this winter campaign, with help from Soro Yiriwaso.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seedlings, fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda R. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old. Rosalinda is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a business selling traditional handicrafts to tourists and local community members. She is also making souvenir items from seashells, beads and coco shells. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosalinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man K., 32, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. She is employed at a local garment factory making an income of US $2 per day. Her husband sells firewood, earning an income of about US $4 per day. K. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase a cow to attach to their cart to transport firewood. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. K.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy a cow to transport firewood to sell

loans.name: Phelix

texts.en: Phelix I. is 27 years old, single and has two children aged three years and nine months old. His business is located at Khayega, a very busy market in Kakamega. He has been supplying milk to the shopkeepers, schools and local customers. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is the large number of other people in the area doing the same kind of business as his. The customers are spoiled by the  choices. There are also some of his debtors who do not pay on time as per the agreement. However, he works very hard to keep her business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to be a supplier of milk in the Western province. He describes himself as visionary, hardworking, and flexible.

loans.use: To buy more items to expand her business

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

Les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 3 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 47ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités hivernales. 
Les spéculations sont le riz, l’arachide et le petit mil. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts passés se sont bien dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Mah Cissé compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir sa superficie culturale.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45 000FCFA par campagne.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi 3 portent toute leur confiance pour le bon déroulement de la campagne hivernale avec l’aide de Soro Yiriwaso.

The ten members of the Benkadi 3 group are married women, on average 47 years old with four children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to undertake successfully their winter campaign activities. They speculate on rice, ground nuts, and millet. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seedlings, fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Le Xa107 Group

texts.en:
Nam T. N. is 39 years old and she lives in Le Xa village, Mai Lam commune.  Nam is married with one child.  To earn a living, she grows rice and makes bamboo brooms to sell. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 VND. 

She has participated in SEDA since 2008. During her last cycle she borrowed 2,436,000 Vietnamdong (VND) and repaid punctually.  Now Nam would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy more bamboo to make brooms.

About this group:

Ut T. N. is 30 years old. She would like to borrow 5,014,000 VND to expand her store.
Nguyet T. D. is 47 years old. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.use: Buy bamboo to make brooms.

loans.name: Gombe Tukolerewamu Women's Group, Mpigi

texts.en:
Widowed, 55-year-old N. Florence has, for the last twelve years, been banking on her general merchandise retail shop business in Gombe, Mpigi, to earn her source of livelihood. With this business, which has mostly been selling sugar, salt, and rice, she has been able to make ends meet in terms of providing for her family, primarily her six children’s education.

Florence began this business with the modest savings she had in the bank. Her lack of experience in running a business, did not impact her much at the threshold of her business. She had the courage of her conviction that she would succeed, even without any prior pedigree in business.

Florence describes herself as an optimist who will do anything to achieve success in whatever she bears a hand in. She also wants her kids to emulate her example and join her in business as this type of business is currently the most reliable source of income for most Ugandans, especially those who have just finished their studies.

In a week, Florence says she makes profits that are to the tune of 100,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to specifically purchase four bags of sugar, five jerry cans of cooking oil, ten boxes of soap, one bag of rice, etc.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items such as sugar, cooking oil and rice

loans.name: Prak

texts.en: The photo shows Prak P. with his wife at their home.  Prak is 32 years old and a resident of Kompong Tom Province.  To pursue a daily income, he owns a motorbike and operates a taxi service.  Beside his taxi business, Prak and his wife grow a few crops on their land next to their house for extra income.  They have one child who attends school.  The coming rainfall is good for growing, however, Prak needs a loan to buy fertilizers, insecticides and seeds for planting.

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizers, insecticides and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Benkadi  4 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Benkadi 4 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 47 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres  l’arachide et le petit mil. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Baya C. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  3 hectares.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 45.000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Benkadi 4 group are married women, on average 47 years old with four children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their activities at the start of the winter campaign. The crops they speculate on are ground nuts and millet, among others. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. With this new loan, Baya C. intends to buy seedlings and fertiliser before prices increase, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate three hectares (approx. 7.5 acres). The crops are sold after harvest in Nangola and the adjoining area, and in the town of Dioïla, to both men and women customers. They hope to attain an average profit of 45,000 FCFA per campaign.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seedlings and fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Thuy's Group

texts.en:
Thuy T. D. is 39 years old. She lives in Luc Canh village, in the Xuan Canh commune. She is married with two children. She grows rice and breeds poultry. She is a very dynamic women, and participates in social activity. She has a monthly income of about 3,000,000 Vietnamdong (VND). She is the leader of a 5-member group though SEDA. She has participated in SEDA since 2006 and repaid punctually. In this loan cycle, she would like to borrow 4,142,000 VND to breed poultry.

About the other borrowers in her group:
Thanh T. N. N. is 50 years old. She wants to borrow 4,142,000 VND to buy food for pigs.
Mai T. B. N. is 27 years old. She wants to borrow 2,834,000 VND to breed  pigs.
Luat T. N. is 60 years old. She wants to borrow 5,014,000 VND to buy food for pigs.
Linh T. N. is 29 years old. She wants to borrow 5,450,000 VND to buy bamboo to make brooms.

loans.use: To breed poultry

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora C. is from the village of Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old. Flora is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Flora owns & operates a business buying ready to wear items like pants, skirts, sandals and shorts and selling them in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for less than a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Flora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Flora is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Flora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Pech

texts.en: Pech S. is a 54 year-old widow farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province.  She is blessed with five children, three are married and the others are single. Pech's daughter appears on the left of the photo.  They work together as farmers.  They are able to plant crops at least twice a year.  The coming rainfall is good for growing, but Pech needs a loan to plant seeds and to tend to a crop.

loans.use: Farming

Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage.
