loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita L. is from the village of Lalawan Dicayas. She is 42 years old, married and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Rita owns and operates a business that provides repair services to community members.  Rita has been in business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Rita joined PMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Rita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC.  Rita is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to buy electrical materials. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

--------------------------------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Buy electrical materials.

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Eng O. (wife in photo) is a 42-year-old married man and father. He lives with other family members in his small home in Kompong Tom Province.  He owns a piece of land that he inherited from his grandmother.  Eng and his wife grow different kinds of crop on the land, like potato, cucumbers and rice that he sells to customers.  They have four kids.  Eng O. is taking out his first loan to purchase insecticide, fertilizer and seeds.

loans.use: Purchase insecticide, fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Lila

texts.en:
Lila G., 49, is from the village of Larayan, Dapitan City. She is married and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Lila owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community.  Lila has been  in business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2006, Lila joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities.  Lila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase products to sell.  Lila is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP to purchase additional products to sell and for medication of her husband.  This loan will be her 9th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

--------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase products to sell and medication of her husband.

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana N., 56, is from the city of Estaka, Dipolog City. She is married and has four adult-aged children.  To make a living, Feliciana owns and operates a store that sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community.  She has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Feliciana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Feliciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from PMPC to expand her business.  Feliciana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.  This loan will be her 8th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Benkadi  7 Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf membres du groupe Benkadi 7 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide et le petit mil. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Faty B. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 35000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
The nine members of the Benkadi 7 group are married women, on average 43 years old with four children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their activities at the start of the winter campaign. The crops they speculate on are ground nuts and millet, among others. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. With this new loan, Faty B. intends to buy seedlings and fertiliser before prices increase, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate approximately 2.5 hectares (6 acres). The crops are sold after harvest in Nangola and the adjoining area, and in the town of Dioïla, to both men and women customers. They hope to attain an average profit of 35,000 FCFA per campaign.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seedlings and fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina O., 72, is a widow from the village of Mapang. She has one adult-aged child.  To make a living, Agustina owns and operates a general store, selling household items in the local community.  Agustina has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Agustina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Agustina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 65,000 PHP from PMPC.  Agustina is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP for additional capital for her business. This loan will be her 12th from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

---------------------------------------
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen D. is from the village of San Vicente, Dapitan City. She is 36 years old and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Helen owns and operates a business that provides manicures and pedicures to local residents. Helen has been in business for over one year and earns approximately 1,600 PHP a month.

In 2009, Helen joined PMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,900 PHP from PMPC.  Helen is requesting a new loan of 4,900 PHP to purchase materials needed for manicure and pedicure services. This loan will be her 3rd loan from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

---------------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase materials needed for manicure and pedicure services.

loans.name: Ardah

texts.en: Ardah N. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in the Bayan-Ulgiy province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Ardah operates a retail meat business in his town. He began his business in 2005 and after several years of operation, he has managed to establish himself in the business community. Ardah has been living in the province for 18 years. He purchases a sheep, slaughters and sells it at the retail price. His working capital is 500,000 MNT and he earns 10,000 to 15,000 MNT profit from per sheep. He is not open-minded but he is a hardworking person. Ardah is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase his working capital as well as expanding his house and improving his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Benkadi 8 Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf membres du groupe Benkadi 8 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide et le petit mil. 
Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Mah F. compte  acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 4 hectares.
Les productions seront vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA par campagne, Mah espère réaliser 50.000 FCFA.
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi 8 portent toute leur confiance pour le bon déroulement de la campagne hivernale avec l’aide de Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The nine members of the Benkadi 8 group are married women, on average 43 years old with four children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their activities at the start of the winter campaign. The crops they speculate on are ground nuts and millet, among others. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. With this new loan, Mah F. intends to buy seedlings and fertiliser before prices increase, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate 4 hectares (approx. 10 acres). The crops are sold after harvest in Nangola and the adjoining area, and in the town of Dioïla, to both men and women customers. Whereas the other group members hope for an average profit of 40,000 FCFA per campaign, Mah hopes to attain 50,000 FCFA. The women of the Benkadi 8 group place all their trust in the successful progress of this winter campaign, with help from Soro Yiriwaso.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seedlings and fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria M., 55, is from the village of Southwestern Poblacion. She has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Gloria making and selling food, mostly snacks and other delicacies in the local community.  Gloria has been in business for over 12 years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month.

In 2004, Gloria joined PMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP to pay for the driver's license of her son.  This loan will be her 8th from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

---------------------------------
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Pay for the driver's license for her son.

loans.name: Apolinaria

texts.en:
Apolinaria P., 55, is widow from the village of Antipolo, Dapitan City. She is 55 years old. Apolinaria has 11 adult-aged children.  To make a living, Apolinaria raises crops, planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale.  Apolinaria has been in business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,900 PHP a month.

In 2008, Apolinaria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Apolinaria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,500 PHP from PMPC.  Apolinaria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her 6th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her living conditions. 

-------------------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Djiguisseme 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Djiguisseme 1 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz,  l’arachide et le petit mil. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt de campagne et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, Sali Traoré qui cultive toutes ces spéculations compte acheter, des intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir 5 hectares. Il est à noter que la superficie cultivée par le groupe est de 25 hectares environs.
Les productions seront vendues au niveau du village de Nangola et environnants et dans la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Djiguisseme 1 group are married women, on average 42 years old with three children. Most live in polygamous families in Nangola, one of the villages in the Dioïla Prefecture of the Koulikouro region, which belongs to the 2nd administrative region of Mali. They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to better organise their activities at the start of the winter campaign. The crops they speculate on are rice, ground nuts and millet, among others. This is their fifth campaign loan, and all previous loans were well reimbursed. With this new loan, Sali Traoré -who cultivates all of the cash crops- intends to buy seedlings and fertiliser before prices increase, small farming equipment and pay labor costs to cultivate 5 hectares (approx. 12 acres). One should note the the area cultivated by the group amounts to approximately 25 hectares (62 acres). The crops are sold after harvest in Nangola and the adjoining area, and in the town of Dioïla, to both men and women customers. They hope to reach an average profit of 40,000 FCFA per campaign.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Seedlings and fertiliser, small farming equipment and labor costs

loans.name: Tsogjargal

texts.en: Tsogjargal B., age 36, lives in Arhangai province in western Mongolia. He currently operates a mobile timber business in his local area. He began this business in 2001, with working capital of 200,000 MNT and since then he has been operating the business steadily. Today, his working capital exceeds 3,200,000 MNT. Tsogjargal is hardworking and is trusted by his many customers as a very reliable supplier. He is very optimistic about the future and hopes to one day expand his business. He says, “I want to create my own workplace in the future”. Tsogjargal is modest, creative and very keen on expanding his business to improve his quality of life. He is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase wood and timber in order to sell in neighbor provinces and the countryside.

loans.use: To purchase wood and timber

loans.name: 02.03.05-Hoang Dong-Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Nga C. T. (28) is a 40-year-old female living in the town of Hoang Hoa-Thanh Hoa.  Nga is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 02.03.05 Hoang Hoa (02.03.05-Hoang hoa).


Nga is married and has three school-aged children.  To make a living, Nga operates a family member's business venture raising cattle for sale.  Nga has been engaged in this business for over 15 years and earns approximately 900,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2006, Nga joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Nga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the fourth loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Nga plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. T. Lay (30) is a 56-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


2.  N. T. Hoa (32) is a 36-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


3.  N. T. Ly (31) is a 40-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


4.  N. T. Hanh (65) is a 32-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


5.  N. T. Ha (29) is a 38-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Nga C. T. (28) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa- Thanh Hoa.  Nga là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 02.03.05 Hoang Hoa (02.03.05-Hoang hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Nga thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 15 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Nga kiếm được khoảng 900,000 VND.  Vào 2006, Nga đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Nga đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. T. Lay (30) là 56 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  N. T. Hoa (32) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  N. T. Ly (31) là 40 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  N. T. Hanh (65) là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  N. T. Ha (29) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: C2363 Turibamwe Group

texts.en:
Saverine is 58 years old and married with three children who are 20, 26 and 28 years old.  Saverine is the president of a group called "Turibamwe" and this group puts their strengths together in order to expand their businesses meaningfully.  Her business hours are from 5 am to 8 pm every day.

Although Saverine and her team do all their best in order to expand meaningfully, their capital is still too low to earn enough profit.  To end this, Saverine is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business by adding a large quantity of foodstuffs.  If successful, Saverine and her team will keep reinvesting for better financial stability and saving for a better future.

loans.use: To  buy a large quantity of foodstuffs

loans.name: Katojo Development Association, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
Hardworking K. Joram, aged 42, is the married father of seven children. He went into a carpentry business venture close to twenty-four years ago, having got this idea from his close friend.

Having a strategically located business in Buyanja, Kihihi town, in western Uganda, Joram gets many customers, earning him 400,000 Ugandan shillings monthly.

With this loan, Joram is looking forward to making purchases and restocking his business with more materials like timber and nails and also doing more advertising to increase the number of his customers. This will definitely give his enterprise a new push and also help him improve on his sales. Thus, he will also be able to take good care of his family requirements as his goal is to have his children educated to higher levels.

Joram also makes side profits from a small commercial farming business which was originally his main source of income before he ventured into carpentry.

loans.use: To purchase more  timber, nails, etc., and also to pay for radio adverts for his business

loans.name: Djiguisseme 3 Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Djiguisseme 3 sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 21 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Nangola, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.

loans.name: Dolele Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DOLELE est un des groupes de  solidarité du Banc Villageois de RANDOULENE SUD, il est composé de 18 femmes toutes issues du même quartier. Elles sont toutes mariées et mères d'au moins de deux enfants exceptée Lobé M. (responsable du groupe), mais elle a l'entière charge d'un de ses neveux qui fréquente l'école. Le groupe est constitué de femmes relativement âgées de 21 à 40 ans, seules les quatre premières au second rang sur la photo de la gauche vers la droite ont plus de la quarantaine. Elles développent des activités diverses, à savoir le petit commerce d'effets vestimentaires, de produits cosmétiques, de produits halieutiques et certaines font de l'élevage de volailles et de l'embouche ovine.

Madame Adji Aïda M., pour des raisons liées à la santé de son enfant n'a pas pu être présente lors de la prise de photo. Elle est adjointe à la responsable du groupe, elle est âgée de 21 ans. Elle fait de l'élevage de volaille et l'embouche ovine et elle est appuyée par son mari pour mener à bien son activité.

Mademoiselle Lobé M., en deuxième position, accroupie au premier rang de la droite vers la gauche sur la photo et mise en médaillon, est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est la plus jeune du groupe mais c'est dû à son assiduité, son sérieux dans le travail et sa bonne culture d'esprit de solidarité qu'elle a été responsabilisée. Elle est âgée de 21 ans et célibataire sans enfant mais à la charge de garçon de sa sœur. Depuis son adhésion dans le Banc Villageois en 2009 elle vend des parfums et son nouveau prêt lui permettra de développer et promouvoir son activité. Son objectif est de renforcer son niveau d'épargne, de prendre en charge ses besoins personnels et ceux de l'enfant dont elle a la charge.
texts.en:
The DOLELE group is one of the solidarity groups of the RANDOULENE SUD "Banc Villageois." It is made up of eighteen women, all from the same neighborhood. They are all married and the mothers of at least two children, with the exception of Lobé M. (group leader); however, she is entirely responsible for one of her nephews, who is in school. The women of the group are between 21 and 40 years old, with the exception of the first four standing on the left, who are in their forties. They are developing diverse businesses, such as sales of clothing, cosmetics, and fishing supplies. Others raise poultry and fatten sheep. For reasons related to the health of her child, Mrs. Adji Aïda M. could not be present for the photo. She is assistant group leader; she is 21 years old. She raises poultry and fattens sheep, and she is assisted in her business by her husband. Miss Lobé M., second from the right on the front row and also in closeup, is the group leader. She is the youngest of the group, but she became group leader thanks to her diligence, dependability, and understanding of community spirit. She is 21 years old, single, and childless, although she supports her sister's son. Since joining the "Banc Villageois" in 2009, she has been selling perfume. Her new loan will allow her to develop and market her business. Her goals are to build her savings level and to pay her personal expenses, as well as those of the child she supports.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen the business activities of group members

loans.name: Abida

texts.en:
Abida A. lives in a city called Riawind in Pakistan, which is about 30 km away from Lahore. Her husband runs a shop in a nearby market where he sells betel nuts and cigarettes. He has been doing this business for the last 20 years and it proves to be profitable for him.  Abida has three children, two sons and a daughter. Her daughter is getting her education and is in fifth standard while her sons left their education after completing eighth standard. Both now do jobs to support the family financially. Abida is also a working woman. She does sewing work by taking orders from her neighborhood to supplement her income. She is also a very good mother who takes care of her children very well and gives them proper time. 
She is a regular client of Asasah and her repayment record is very good. Now she is applying for a loan for the fifth time from Asasah. She will invest the loan amount in her husband’s business. He will buy betel leaves and different brands of cigarettes to sell at his shop.  Abida hopes that her experience with her Asasah loan will be as great this time as the previous times.

Note: "She has her sister''s kid in this photo".

loans.use: To purchase cigarettes & betel nuts and leaves

loans.name: Great People Group

texts.en:
Mama N., the woman holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Great People. She is 35 years old, single and has six children who range from 5 to 19 years old. She describes herself as hard working and serviceable. Her plan is to improve her business and educate her children.

For 3 years, she has been selling charcoal in Jacob’s Town community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of charcoal.  

She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 55 years old. He is married with 10 children between the ages of 7 and 31. Five of the children are currently attending school.

He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. Patrick has been farming for 30 years and has two casual employees. His main product is milk and maize, which he sells to the local market. He is also employed as a teacher in the same area.

His biggest challenge in farming has been disease, which is a threat to his dairy cows.

Patrick has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 62,400 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk to sell and increase his income. He believes that the extra income from this loan will reduce his stress level caused by financial constraints.

In the future, he would like to increase his productivity by acquiring a high-yielding dairy cow.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Chemwachar

texts.en:
Chemwachar is 54 years old. He is married with no children. He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. He has been practising mixed farming for 20 years and producing milk and maize, which he sells locally. He is also an agricultural contractor and earns an income from his services to the local people.

His biggest challenge in farming is the fluctuation in the prices of milk and the high cost of farm inputs.

He has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 93,600 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk to sell. The extra income from this loan will assist him meet his basic needs.

In five years time, he hopes to have increased his productivity by 50 percent.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Abakundana Group

texts.en:
Marcelline is 38 years old and married with five children who are between 7 and 21 years old.  Marceline is the president of a group called Abakundana.  This group owns a restaurant where they cook food for their daily profits.  This restaurant is open from early in the morning until late in the evening hours.

Marceline and her team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase equipment and increase the food they cook for their customers.  With this loan, this group will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow them to create as many sources of income as possible.  Through the creation of these new sources of income, each member of this group will continue taking care of her family and save for the future.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and food for the restaurant

loans.name: Women Of Faith Group

texts.en:
Comfort H., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Women Of Faith.  She is 45 years old, married and has four children who range from 20 to 27 years old.  She is a graduate of Teacher Training School.  Comfort cares for three siblings. 

For 10 years, Comfort has been selling bread, cookies, farina and beans in Jacob’s Town community, outside Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy flour, farina and beans. She describes herself as quiet and jovial.  Her goal is to improve her business and transform it into a bakery.

loans.use: Buy flour, farina and beans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Eliseo

texts.en:
Eliseo D. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 45 years old. Eliseo is single. To make a living, Eliseo owns & operates a business providing transportation services to local community members. Eliseo has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eliseo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eliseo has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Eliseo is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a set of tires for his motorcycle and for the repair and maintenance of his motorcycle to continue his transport business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Eliseo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and to repair and maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Nyabitanda Tukore Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
As they say, determination is a key to success, and R. Jackson, a happily married father of four children, ventured into a commercial tea-growing business in Kanyabuhoma, Kihihi, thirteen years ago with much vigor. This was after realizing that there is a readily available market in the area for tea leaves. Prior to that, he was into subsistence farming, mostly growing cassava.

This commercial tea growing business sees Jackson earning 60,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis and this has had a great impact on his standard of living. His main disadvantage has been the low fertility of his gardens. He calculates that with his hard work nature, he would be making more money if it was not for the lack of fertilizers.

Therefore, with this loan, Jackson is looking at buying fertilizers and manure and further expanding his tea plantation through buying more seedlings and doing it on a large scale. This will improve his yields and his sales and enable him to take care of his family’s needs.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, manure and seedlings

loans.name: Celine

texts.en:
Celine is 38 years old and married with seven children who are between 1 and 15 years old.  Celine lives by selling a variety of goods in her shop and this is her sixth successful year in this business.  Celine opens her shop from 7 am until 6 am every day.

Celine, after realizing that her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Celine will hopefully earn more profits through the sale of foodstuffs as they are highly demanded by a large number of customers. This in turn, will allow her to keep reinvesting and saving for better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetic goods and foodstuffs

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros L. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 59 years old. Milagros is married. To make a living, Milagros owns & operates a business providing video karaoke services or sing-along business to local community members. She caters to singing for a fee of 5 pesos per song. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Milagros joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional tables and chairs for her sing-along business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Milagros from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tables and chairs for her karaoke business

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Tièssiri sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames ayant en moyenne 44 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le  commerce de draps de lits, des vêtements, de la friperie, de la viande grillée (brochettes) et de la friture de farine de blé. 
Dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités génératrices de revenus, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 9ème cycle de prêt solidaire. Tous  les huit prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
 Madame Oumou D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 4 balles (colis) de friperie  au marché Médine de Bamako avec les grossistes. 
La vente se fait en détail au comptant ou à crédit, à domicile, au marché Château de Ségou et en ambulant dans les quartiers de Ségou à une clientèle mixte. 
Madame Oumou D. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité, épargner et assurer l’éducation de leurs enfants à l’école.
texts.en:
The members of the Tièssiri group are married women, the majority of whom live in monogamous families; they average 44 years of age and have an average of five children each. They all live in the Hamdallaye district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and met through neighbors and through their income-generating activities at the Château de Ségou market. The members of the group sell bed sheets, clothes, second-hand clothes, grilled meat (kebabs) and wheat-flour fritters. In order to sustain their income-generating activities, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and are on the ninth group loan. All the eight previous loans were repaid on time. Their sales are made on a retail basis for cash and on credit, at home, at the Château de Ségou market and on a door-to-door basis in the various districts of Ségou, to a mixed customer base. Mrs. Oumou D. is hoping to make an average monthly profit of 40,000FCFA with this loan; the profit will be reinvested in her activity, put aside as savings and used to cover her children's schooling.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase second-hand clothes

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Cerue B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called In God We Trust.  She is 25 years old, single and has four children who range from 5 to 9 years old. Cerue was only able to attend school through 11th grade, due to lack of financial support.  For four years she has sold peanuts in the Pipeline Road community, outside Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more bags of peanuts.  She describes herself as easy going and friendly.  Her goal is to improve her business and transform it into a bakery.

loans.use: Buy more bags of peanuts.

loans.name: Rosa Rafael

texts.pt:
Rosa Rafael C. vive na cidade da Matola, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique. Possui um negócio próprio de compra e venda de produtos da primeira necessidade. No empréstimo passado foi possível comprar a mercadoria que esteve prevista e a quantidade desejada.
Conseguiu pagar a sua letra de acordo com o seu calendário e o seu negócio tem andado bem embora com uma ligeira quebra devido a subida do valor do Rand, a moeda sul-africana onde tem adquirido a maioria do seu produto. Com o rendimento do seu negócio conseguiu melhorar a situação financeira da sua família.
O presente empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt pretende comprar produtos alimentares e roupa diversa usada para aumentar a quantidade do stock. O empréstimo foi satisfatório, melhorou bastante a sua vida, a sua filha casou se oficialmente. No futuro pretende solicitar mais crédito para apostar no melhoramento do seu negócio, separando estabelecimento de roupa a de produtos alimentares.
texts.en:
Rosa Rafael C. lives in the city of Matola, in the Maputo province, in the south of Mozambique. She runs her own business buying and selling consumer products. The past loan made it possible for her to buy merchandise in the quantity she wanted. She was able to repay the loan on time and her business has done well, but has taken a small loss due to the drop in value of the Rand (the currency used in South Africa, which is where she purchases the majority of her products). With the revenue she earns from her business, she has been able to improve the financial situation of her family.

The previous loan was for 25,000MT, and she used this amount to purchase food products and diverse clothing, which augmented her quantity of stock. The loan was satisfactory, and improved her life, and her daughter was able to get married. In the future, she hopes to access more loans to further improve her business, separating the clothing store from her food products.

Translated from Portuguese by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of consumer products and varied used clothing

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en: Nenita C. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 40 years old. Nenita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Nenita runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Nenita from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Laul Group

texts.en:
Najeeba is a member of Laul group. She lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with 3 children who are enrolled in school. She is a beautician. She has got a small beauty salon in her house. She has been involved in this business for more than 7 years. In this way she can help her husband support their children as well.

She needs the loan to purchase some new quality cosmetics such as hair rollers, eye shadow, and some chairs and a new table as well. She hopes to have more progress in her business.

loans.use: buying good quality cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Amelita

texts.en:
Amelita P. is from the village of Lugait Misamis oriental. She is 55 years old, married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Amelita owns & operates a specialized retail store that sells a variety of household items to the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Amelita joined HSPFI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Amelita is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Amelita's 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her retail store.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Timinandiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Timinandiya sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants  et habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit  de sucre, de jus de gingembre, de savons et de bazins teintés. 
Dans le besoin d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Fatoumata D. est beaucoup sollicitée à Hamdallaye pour la qualité de sa teinture et de ses bazins choisis. Elle a comme surnom Fanta Gala c'est-à-dire  en Bambara : Fanta la teinture. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 10 pièces de bazins, 300g de colorants  de diverses couleurs, un sac de sel iodé et 1kg de potasse au grand marché de Bamako. Pour teinter une pièce de bazin, elle fait bouillir de l’eau, ajoute des colorants en fonction de la couleur voulue, de la potasse et du sel. Quand le mélange devient homogène, elle imbibe la pièce de bazin dans cela pendant 15 minutes au moins puis elle l’étale au soleil pour le séchage. 
La vente  de ses bazins teintés se fait au comptant ou à crédit et parfois sur commande, à domicile, au marché Château de Ségou et en ambulant dans les quartiers de Ségou à une clientèle mixte. 
Madame Fatoumata D. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et épargner. Elle a pour  ambition  d’ouvrir un atelier d’artisanat pour la teinture.
texts.en:
The members of the Timinandiya group are primarily married women who live in monogamous households. They are around 40 years old with four children, and all live in the Hamdallaye quarter of Ségou, the fourth largest administrative region in Mali; they met through neighbours, family and through their business activities at the Château de Ségou market. The group's members sell sugar, ginger juice, soap and dyed 'bazins'. In order to increase their business funds, the members of the group have called upon the Soro Yiriwaso credit association and are on their second loan. Madame Fatoumata D. is sought-after in Hamdallaye thanks to the quality of her dyes and bazins. Her nickname in Bambara is 'Fanta Gala', which means 'Fanta the dye-expert.' She aims to use her loan to buy 10 bazins, 300g of different colour dyes, a bag of iodised salt and 1kg of potash from the large market at Bamako. In order to dye a piece of bazin, she boils water, adds the dyes according to the required colour, then adds potash and salt. When the mixture is consistent, she immerses the piece of bazin in it for 15 minutes and then flattens it out in front of the sun in order to dry it. She sells these dyed bazins for cash or credit, sometimes on demand, at home, at the Château de Ségou and from mobile sales around the local quarters; her customer base is made up of men and women. She hopes to use this loan to generate an average monthly profit of 28000 FCFA which she would use to reinvest in her business, and also for savings. Her goal is to open a dyeing studio.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase white bazins and raw materials for dyeing them

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma B. is from the village of Benhaan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 34 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns & operates a retail trading business.  The main source of income for her business is buying raw green bananas and other crops like copra and sweet potato from neighboring villages and selling them to the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Emma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more crops to sell. This will be Emma's 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase more crops to sell

loans.name: Ana Isabel

texts.pt:
Ana Isabel Manuel C. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos de 7 e 5 anos de idade, vão a escola. Fez somente 2ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos progenitores mas tem esperança de um dia voltar a escola. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém para além de seus filhos.
Saiu da sua cidade natal para Inhambane a procura de melhores condições de vida, 10 anos depois regressa a cidade da Matola. Tem um negócio próprio de criação de frangos de corte ha mais de 12 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua irmã que Ja teve empréstimo nesta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar pintos, rações e vitaminas para aumentar a quantidade do seu stock. 
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para ampliar os seus aviários meter mais frangos.
texts.en:
Ana Isabel Manuel C. was born in the city of Matola in the Maputo province, in the south of Mozambique. She is a single mother of two children, who are 7 and 5 years old, and both attend school. She only attended through 2nd grade and did not continue due to her parents' lack of finances. She lives in her own home with her family and she does not support anyone else besides her children.

She left her birth city for Inhambane to pursue better living conditions. Ten years later, she returned to Matola. She has a business raising chickens and has done this for more than 12 years. She doesn't have any employees and earns about 5,000MT monthly, which she applies to her household expenses and still saves some to her bank account.

She has never taken out a loan with another bank. She came to know Hluvuku through her sister who had already received a loan from the institution. This is her first loan for the amount of 25,000MT, which she plans to use to purchase feed and vitamins to increase the quantity of her stock. She promises to repay this loan dutifully to be able to access others. In the future she hopes to seek more loans to expand her aviaries to fit more chickens.

Translated from Portuguese by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of chicken feed and vitamins

loans.name: Ma. Villamor

texts.en:
Ma. Villamor A. is from the village of  Manticao  , Misamis Oriental. She is 41 years old. Ma. Villamor is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Ma. Villamor owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food & daily use products to the local community. Ma. Villamor has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month..

In 2009, Ma. Villamor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase more products for sale. Ma. Villamor is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.   This will be her 5th loan from HSPFI and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mary Trailyn

texts.en:
Mary Trailyn J. is from the village of  Port Area , Iligan City. She is 28 years old. married and has an infant child. To make a living, Mary Trailyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food & daily use products to the local community. Mary Trailyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Mary Trailyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Trailyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products for sale. Mary Trailyn is requesting a new loan of 13000 PHP which, once again, will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be Mary Trailyn's 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa N., a 52-year-old resident of Hinaplanon, Iligan City, is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Elsa owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 10000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan, her fourth, for 13000 PHP to be used for the same purpose. Elsa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Djamilya

texts.en:
B. Djamilya is 24 years old. She is divorced and has a little child. She lives with her parents. Djamilya is selling women’s clothing and shoes in the local market. She has been in this business for 3 years. Djamilya is a friendly and polite woman. She is trying to diversify the range of goods she sells to satisfy the needs of clients with various levels of income. However, the majority of the goods are attractive for customers with average incomes.

The business is stable, allowing Djamilya to make a considerable contribution to the family budget. Now Djamilya is planning to purchase new clothing in order to increase her stock of goods. For this purpose she requests $1,000 US. Djamilya thanks all supporting her and promises to pay the loan in a timely manner. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family.

loans.name: Moises Israel

texts.pt:
Moisés Israel M. nasceu no Distrito de Chongoene, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, casado e pai de 6 filhos cuja as idades Ja não se lembra, mas os 2 mais novos vão a escola. Fez somente 1ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Saiu de Gaza para Boane com seu pai ainda menor de idade. Actualmente trabalha como guarda segurança na empresa SOCEL ha mais de 24 anos, onde também possui um negócio próprio de compra e venda de cobertores. Neste negócio consegue um rendimento de cerca de 22.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua vizinha que Ja solicitou crédito nesta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 13.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar cobertores, duvetes e lençóis para aumentar a sua mercadoria.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para ampliar a sua residência e construir um estabelecimento comercial mais condigno.
texts.en:
Moisés Israel M. was born in Chongoene District, Gaza Province in southern Mozambique. He is married and has 6 children whose ages he does not remember right now, but the two youngest go to school. Moisés only finished first grade and did not continue with school because of financial difficulties. He lives in his own house with his family and does not support anyone else. He left Gaza to move to Boane with his father when he was still young. Moisés currently works as a security guard at SOCEL, where he has worked for more than 24 years. He also has a business buying and selling bedcovers. With this business he has an income of close to 22,000 meticais per month, which he uses for household expenses. He also saves some money through Xitique (a traditional system of rotating savings). Moisés has never had loans from other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through his neighbor who had already requested a loan from this institution. This is his first loan. He is asking for 13,000 meticais to buy blankets, duvet covers and sheets to expand his inventory. He promises to pay off this loan on time so he can take out other loans. In the future he would like to ask for more loans to add on to his house and build a nicer shop.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase blankets, duvet covers and sheets

loans.name: Kholbibi

texts.en:
S. Kholbibi is an enterprising, capable, and very hard-working woman. She lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan and sells men’s clothes. She began her own business because her husband was unemployed for some time. Her work is allowing her children go to school. It is very important to Kholbibi that her children finish school and become honest, hard-working individuals. You can help Kholbibi provide for the education of her children. She needs a loan of $1000 US to buy merchandise in order to increase sales. Kholbibi wants to continue to support her children and only wishes to work in order to achieve this.

loans.name: Uamsho Group

texts.fr:
la cliente,  W. est  entrepreneur, productrice de boisson locale communément appelé  « Rutuku » , elle lève courageusement sa main  sur la photo,  excellente cliente de banque communautaire « Uamsho »,  âgée de 44 ans, veuve, mère de 3 enfants(2 garçons et une fille).Le  fils ainé  étudie en 2e graduat (bac), le second avait refusé les études et le cadet fait la 3e primaire.  La veuve  Manda W. réside dans le quartier  périphérique de majengo, bidon ville de la ville de Goma 
Son mari fut victime et décédé dans la guerre de 1996 dit de « libération » de l’AFDL (Alliance de Force Démocratique pour la Libération du Congo), mouvement politico militaire dirigé par le défunt président Laurent Désiré Kabila, qui a renversé le pouvoir dictatorial du défunt président Mobutu Seseseko. 
 De façon sommaire, « Rutuku » est une boisson  alcoolisée d’environ 47% produite en base de solution ou mélange des fermentations  et moisissures des Farine de manioc, maïs, sorgho, etc. chauffée au feu à plus de 180o C , à travers une vase connectée à un cheminé d’évacuation de technologie locale. Les goutes raffinées d’évaporation issue de ce cheminé sont accueillies dans une cuvette et  refroidies pour donner un gout d’une liqueur whisky fort apprécié par les consommateurs (soulards). 
 La veuve  Manda W. a commencé son petit commerce  avec  son fonds propre d’une valeur de 30$ par la fabrication  et vente de beignets (Ndazi). Malheureusement  les recettes de vente de beignets étaient insuffisantes pour couvrir toutes les charges familiales, ainsi elle a préféré diversifier les activités  et commencer à ventre la boisson locale. En plus de cette activité. La veuve  Manda W. vend aussi la bière Primus, Fanta, pour accroitre ses revenus.
Avec  le crédit  de  l’IMF Hekima, la veuve  Manda W. souhaite augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en achetant  2 sacs de sucres, 15 paquets de levure (pour la fabrication des beignets), 1 sac de des Maïs, 2 sacs de farines maniocs, 4 tas de bois de chauffage (pour production boisson), etc. 
La veuve  Manda W., explique le défi majeur de son activité de production de boissons locales Rutuku est lié aux ventes au crédit. En plus parfois lorsque le mélange des intrants n’a pas bien être solutionné, on produit une boisson non appréciée par les consommateurs, et les clients se réservent de l’acheter.
La  veuve Manda W. a déjà acheté sa propre parcelle pour son fils, elle compte y construire une maison. En outre elle  souhaite marier  pour son fils qui avait  engrossé une fille, aujourd’hui, ils ont déjà 2 enfants ensembles sans pour autant verser la dot auprès de sa famille. 
Le groupe Uamsho est composé de 13 femmes. La veuve  Manda W. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  les crédits  qu’elle reçoit sans aucune garantie matérielle car grâce à ces crédits, elle parvient à subvenir aux besoins de ses enfants orphelins.
texts.en:
W., the client, is an entrepreneur and produces a local drink called 'Rutuku'. In the photo she is bravely raising her arm. She is an excellent customer of the Uamsho credit association, and is a 44 year old widowed mother of three (two boys and a girl). Her elder son is studying in his second year (bac exam year), the second pulled out of his studies, and the youngest is in the third year of primary school. Manda W. lives in the outer quarter of Majengo, a shanty town in Goma. Her husband was a victim of the 1996 war and so-called 'liberation' of the AFDL (Alliance of Democratic Force for the Liberation of the Congo), a military-political movement led by the former president Laurent Désiré Kabila who overturned the dictatorial power of president Mobutu Seseseko, 'Rutuku' is an alcoholic beverage made from a mixture of fermentations and manioc flour, corn, sorghum etc that are heated to over 180 degrees C, then passed through a flask connected to a chimney outlet made locally. The refined drops are then collected in a flask and cooled in order to create a strong whiskey-like taste that is appreciated greatly by her customers. Manda W. began her business activity with $30 of her own money, which went towards the production and sale of doughnuts (Ndazi). Unfortunately the sales of doughnuts were not enough to pay all her family's costs, and so she diversified her business and started to sell the local drink. In addition to this, she sells Primus beer and Fanta to boost her revenue. She would use a loan to purchase 2 bags of sugar, 15 packs of yeast (for the production of doughnuts), one bag of corn, two bags of manioc flour, 4 heaps of firewood (for the production of the drink), etc. She has explained that the major challenge in producing the drink is to do with credit sales. But also, sometimes if the ingredients have not been well mixed, her customers do not like the drink that is produced and refrain from buying it. She has already bought a plot of land for her son and aims to build a house on it. She would also like her son to marry the woman with whom he has two children, in order for her dowry to be split among the family. The Uamsho group is made up of 13 women. Manda W. is grateful to Hekima IMF for the loans that she will receive, as with these loans she will be able to see to her fatherless children's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: two bags of sugar, 15 packs of yeast (for doughnuts), one bag of corn, two bags of manioc flour , four heaps of firewood (for production of the drink) etc

loans.name: Zulaikho

texts.en:
Z. Zulaikho is 54 years old. She is widow with three children. For 7 years Zulaikho has been working as a market vendor. She sells plates and dishes of the oriental style in the central local market. These kind of goods are of popular demand among the population. This kind of china is widely used for the dowry of girls and also for family celebrations. The love of her children is the biggest reason for Zulaikho to make an effort to provide what they need. 

Now Zulaikho is planning to enlarge the range of her store's goods. With this purpose she requests 13,000 Somoni. Zulaikho has been an active and strongly motivated client of IMON since 2007. Her credit history makes her eligible to receive new and larger loans. The well being of Zulaikho’s family and her business are in your hands. She and her children are sincerely grateful for your support.

loans.name: Muharam

texts.en:
Muharam is married and has one child. She has a business selling clothing in the small market of Tursunzade. 

Muharam’s business is going well as demand has been very stable over the last 12 years. Muharam is an entrepreneur of high integrity. She is very hard working and energetic. Even when her competitors have similar product or lower prices, clients naturally gravitate to her as she can skillfully make them feel valued, respected and heard. 

Muharam is requesting a loan of 7,000 Somoni to purchase seasonal clothing which will help her to continue stabilizing her business and income so she can support herself and her daughter.

loans.name: Mother Blessing Group

texts.en:
Lorpu J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Mother Blessing'. She is 39 years old, married and has three children who range from 7 to 13 years old. She was not able to attend school due to lack of financial support. 

For 10 years, she has been selling oil and meat in the Christian Community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more oil and meat. She describes herself as a caring woman. Her dream is to grow her business, build a house, and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

 In the photo that accompanies this profile, James is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more oil and meat

loans.name: Maria

texts.pt:
Maria Américo nasceu no Distrito de Morumbeni, Província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique, casada e mae de 1 filho de 19 anos de idade, que vai a escola. Fez 10ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta 2 enteados que vivem com ela.
Saiu de Inhambane para Boane quando seu pai foi transferido em missão de serviço quando ela tinha apenas 2 anos. Trabalha como empregada domestica ha mais de 2 anos, tem um salário de 1.300.00mt por mês que aplica na despesas de casa e com ajuda do seu marido que trabalha como pedreiro consegue poupar algum através de xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 11.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, pedra e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 5.000.00mt, 5.800.00mt, 6.000.00mt para habitação e comercio.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra.
texts.en:
Maria Américo was born in the Morumbeni District, Inhambane Province, in southern Mozambique. She is married and the mother of one son who is 19 years old and attends school. She completed school through the 10th grade but could not continue due to a lack of financial resources. She lives in her own home with her family and supports 2 stepchildren who live with her. She left Inhambane for Boane when her father was transferred for work when she was just 2 years old. She has been working as a maid for over 2 years and has a monthly salary of 1.300.00mt which she uses for household expenses. With the help of her husband who is a stonemason, she is able to save a bit of money through xitique (a traditional rotational savings plan). She has never had a loan with other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through neighbors who are clients of this institution. This is her 4th loan, in the amount of 11.000.00mt, which she will use to purchase construction material (cement, sand, stones, etc.) to continue building her home. Her previous loans were for 5.000.00mt, 5.800.00mt, 6.000.00mt for housing and business. She promises to pay back this loan on schedule in order to have access to additional loans. In the future she plans to request more loans to complete construction.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of construction material (cement, sand, stone, etc. )
