loans.name: Liene

texts.en:
Liene G. is from the village of Comon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 25 years old. Liene is widowed and has three school-aged children. Liene owns and operates a specialized retail business. She is engaged in selling ready-to-wear items like pants, t-shirts, and even shoes. Another source of income for the family comes from making special native viands like crushed sweet and sour papaya, which she peddles to her neighbors. Liene has been engaged in her business for less than a year and she earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Liene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from HSPFI, which was for 5,000 PHP and was used expand the business. Liene is now requesting her second loan from HSPFI, for 7,000 PHP, which will be used to on the same purpose. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: expanding the business

loans.name: Sope Nabi 2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe SOPE NABI2 est un des groupes de solidarité du Banc Villageois de RANDOULENE SUD, il est composé de 13 femmes toutes issues du même quartier. Elles sont toutes mariées et mères d'au moins de 03 enfants. Elles développent des activités diverses, à savoir le petit commerce d'effets vestimentaires, de produits cosmétiques, de produits halieutiques, de draps de lit et de chaussures. Par contre la responsable du groupe, en sus de son petit commerce fait de la couture.

Madame Maguette N., étant indisponible lors de la prise de photo n'a pas pu être présente.

Aïssatou N., à l’extrême debout à l’extrême droite de la photo, emmitouflée d’une écharpe verte est responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 52 ans, elle est mariée et mère 07 enfants en charge, elle également tutrice d’un garçon et d’une fille. Elle fait la confection et vente de draps de lit. Elle est couturière de profession, c’est depuis qu’elle a quitté l’école il y a de cela 20 ans environs qu’elle a suivi une formation dans ce domaine. Son nouveau crédit lui permettra de mieux développer son activité car l’objet du prêt est de promouvoir ladite activité. Son objectif est de participer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille en ce qui concerne la nourriture, la santé et la scolarité des enfants. Elle soutien aussi son mari qui est admis à la retraite depuis 05 ans.
texts.en:
The SOPE NABI 2 group is one of the solidarity groups of the RANDOULENE SUD “Banc Villageois”. The group is composed of 13 women who all come from the same neighborhood. They are all married and mothers of at least 3 children each. They develop various businesses, that is to say, small businesses selling apparel, cosmetic products, fish products, bed sheets and shoes. The leader of the group, on the other hand, sews in addition to running her small business. Mrs. Maguette N. wasn’t available when the photo was taken and thus wasn’t present. Aïssatou N., standing in the far upper right of the photo wrapped in a green scarf, is the leader of the solidarity group. She is 52 years old, married and the mother of seven dependent children. She also tutors a boy and a girl. She makes ready-to-wear clothing and sells bed sheets. She is a seamstress by profession and received training in this field after leaving school around 20 years ago. Her new loan will enable her to better develop her business because the purpose of the loan is to promote that business. Her objective is to contribute to the improvement of her family’s living conditions in regard to food, health and the education of her children. She also supports her husband who has been retired for five years.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the self-financing capability of the solidarity group

loans.name: Muhabbatkhon

texts.en:
Y. Muhabbatkhon is 39 years old. She is married with two children. Muhabbatkhon is a market vendor. She sells dishes and plates in oriental style in the central local market. Muhabbatkhon has been in this business for 9 years already. Over these years the business turned into a successful one, allowing Muhabbatkhon to support her family and her husband’s parents. Since Muhabbatkhon's husband is currently unemployed, the business generates the main income for the family. 

Now Muhabbatkhon is planning to increase her stock and to purchase dishes and plates wholesale. With this purpose in mind, she requests 7000 Somoni. Muhabbatkhon thanks everyone supporting her and promises to repay the loan in a timely manner. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing dishes and plates wholesale

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites E. is from the village of  Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Marites is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marites joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marites is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Marites from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: United Traders Group

texts.en:
Momo G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'United Traders'.  He is 35 years old, married and has three children who range from 1 to 7 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support.  He cares for two siblings.

For 3 years, he has been selling used tires in Redlight Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 27,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more used tires. He describes himself as kind and easy-going. His dream is to expand his business and open a store.

loans.use: To buy more used tires

loans.name: Norinisso

texts.en:
Norinisso A. is 52 years old. She is married and has two children. Norinisso has been running a grocery store for the past 10 years. She sells sweets, preserved food, juices, soft drinks and also detergents in her grocery. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. 

Norinisso is respectful and patient with all of her customers which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy groceries again. Norinisso is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 4500 Somoni to increase the inventory she has for sale. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Norinisso reach all of her aspirations.

loans.use: Purchasing goods for resale

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian A. is from the village of Comon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old. Lilian is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Lilian owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling specialty food products like sweet and sour crushed papaya  and fresh cucumber salad in the local community. Lilian also sells fruit. She has been engaged in her business for less than a year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lilian joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilian has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Lilian is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Lilian from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Christelle

texts.fr:
Femme commercante de 29 ans,celibataire avec 3 enfants dont l'age varie entre 10 a 8 ans,ayant arrete ses etudes tres jeune par manque de soutien elle se lance en 2000 dans la vente des sacs avec une somme 50.000frs.
Ses recettes journalieres sont d'environ 20000 a 30000 f par jour:
Si le pret lui est donne elle compte renforcer son activite en achetant des lots de sacs de voyage,des valises et des trolleys, c'est des articles qui marchent bien pendant les vacances parceque les gens voyagent beaucoup.Pour la croissance de son activite , elle profite des periodes de vacances pour vendre plus; et choisit des sacs de qualite durable soit en cuir pour interreseer ses clients; malgres les diffucultes elle tient bon pour bien gerer son commerce , puisque cela l'aide a prendre soin des ses enfants et de payer leur scolarite.Ala longue elle est entrain d'epargner pour ouvrir une boutique .Tres enthousiaste, elle a des bonnes relations avec son entourage
texts.en:
This female merchant is 29 years old, single and has 3 children, from 10 to 8 years of age. Having abandoned school at a very young age due to lack of support, she started selling bags in 2000 with 50,000 francs in capital. Her daily revenue varies from circa 20,000 francs to 30,000 francs. If she is granted a loan, she intends to bolster her activity by purchasing batches of travel bags, suitcases and trolleys. These products are popular during vacation, as people travel a lot. To grow her business, she takes advantage of the vacation season to sell more. She selects bags of lasting quality, i.e. in leather, to interest her clients. Despite the difficulties, she holds on in order to run her business well, as it helps her take care of her children and pays for their schooling. She is saving money to open a store in the long run. She is very enthusiastic and has good relationships with those around her.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase travel bags, suitcases and trolleys

loans.name: Abdurasul

texts.en:
A. Abdurasul is an ordinary man from the town of Isfara in Tajikistan. He is a very responsible person who since his youth has been running a livestock farm with the goal of supporting his family, that is, his wife and three children. Abdurasul needs to purchase calves and goats to breed and maximize his profits by selling their milk and meat. Once he has these products from his flock, he sells them in his neighborhood and in this manner he is able to support his family. For this reason, Abdurasul is turning to you for the support that will permit him to continue developing his business.

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Namagainda Faridah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school.  Faridah has a grocery business in Kinoni, where she sells food and produce such as sugar, tomatoes, and onions.  She has had her business for over one year.  Faridah’s business serves the local community by providing a good selection of food to the people in her village.

To expand her business, Faridah is requesting a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for buying more stock of goods to sell in her grocery.  Faridah hopes to expand her grocery business and sell more types of goods, in order to gain more profit and support her young family.


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Additional food items for grocery

loans.name: Saidjon

texts.en:
E. Saidjon is married and has one little kid who he is very proud of since they are struggling to get ahead. With the faith that his family will have a bright future, he started a business of processing and selling dried apricots 7 years ago. He is experienced in this kind of business, and that allows him to expand his clientele day by day. 

Right now Saidjon requests 4000 Somoni. He is going to spend the loan purchasing dried apricots to process and sell. With your help, Saidjon will be able to improve his living conditions.

loans.use: To buy dried apricots to expand his business

loans.name: Kayembe Mixed Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
In Kayembe Trading Centre exists a hardworking and determined A. Frank who has been running a food-selling stall for four years now where he sell foodstuffs like maize, sorghum and beans. The 27-year-old young man has maneuvered through tough times before getting to where he is now. As a matter of fact, it’s his determination and hard work which have brought him this far.

Frank started his business with savings from his agriculture business. He plans on expanding his business in the future so that it can ably compete with other established businesses. In a month, he makes profits that add up to 160,000 shillings.

With this loan, Frank wants restock his business by purchasing crops like peas and rice that he will later resell.

loans.use: To purchase more crops to sell like peas, rice and millet

loans.name: Concern Group

texts.en:
Anthony T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Concern'. He is 28 years old, single, and has one child who is one year old. He is a university student.  For 3 years, he has been involved with a transportation business in  the Paynesville 72nd community, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 4,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy some used tires and spare parts. He describes himself as kind and easy-going. His dream is to expand his business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Frances is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy some used tires and spare parts

loans.name: Firuza

texts.en:
G. Firuza is 39 years old. She is married with 4 children. She started her own business 9 years ago because her husband’s salary as a teacher was not enough to cover their family expenses. Firuza is selling confectionery items such as candies, cookies, and pastries in the local market.  The generated income allows Firuza to support her family and lately she married off her daughter. 

Firuza dreams of educating all of her children through higher education. Today she requests 3500 Somoni. She is going to spend the loan for purchasing confectionery items to expand her range of goods. She is planning to spend the income for the well-being of her family as well as for educating her children.

loans.name: Friendship Group

texts.en:
Kumba S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Friendship'. She is 36 years old, single, and has four children who range from 6 to 18 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to lack of financial support.
 
For 14 years, she has been selling drinks (liquor) and water in Redlight Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more drinks (liquor) and water. She describes herself as a friendly woman.

Her dream is to grow her business and go back to school.

loans.use: To buy more drinks (liquor) and water

loans.name: Djamilakhon

texts.en:
H. Djamilakhon is married and the loving mother of 4 children. With the help of her son (pictured) she sells clothing in her shop which is situated near the famous sanatorium called “Zumrad”. She has a wide variety of merchandise combined with reasonable prices. 

Djamilakhon has been in this trade for 15 years. She is trying to do everything she can to provide for her family and give her children a decent education. That is why she wants to continue expanding her business and growing her trade by increasing the number of her vending locations. Djamilakhon is requesting a loan of 7000 Somoni to sustain her business and help ensure it continues to provide enough income to live on.

loans.name: Poline

texts.en:
N. Poline is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is single, has no children, and is currently out of school.  Poline has a business in Kinoni selling coffee beans to local buyers in her village.  She has had this business for over two years now.

To expand her business, Poline is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for buying greater supplies of coffee beans which she will then resell at her business.  Poline hopes to expand her young coffee business and generate more profit in order to contribute financially to her family. 


Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Additional coffee to sell

loans.name: Hazratali

texts.en:
S. Hazratali is 41 years old. He has had a trying life but he keeps an optimistic outlook. He remains a strong and persevering person, intent on improving his family’s standard of living. Hazratali sells fuel such as petrol and diesel fuel. Over 5 years of selling fuel, he already has got enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him. 

Today Hazratali is requesting a loan of 800 USD that will be used for increasing his inventory to meet his clients' demand. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Hazratali’s business and they will sincerely thank you.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

Mary is 29 years old and is married to a husband who is an electrician. She has one child and her child does not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent out.

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
Y. Munira is a mother of 4 children. She is a very honorable and resolute woman. Ever since she was a young girl, she learned the honest work of raising cattle, the knowledge she has passed down to her own children who have also managed to improve their quality of life. 

Munira and her husband started their livestock business with only one cow. After a number of sacrifices they were able to increase little by little the quantity of calves. At the moment, with the support of their children, they have started to produce milk. They sell it on the weekends in their village. 

Currently Munira wants to expand her business and to purchase more cattle. With the desire of improving their living conditions, Munira is counting on your generous heart.

loans.name: Jalilah

texts.en:
N. Jalilah is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kinoni in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is single and has no children, and currently lives in her family’s home.  Jalilah has a business selling used and new clothes in Kinoni.  She has had her business for approximately one year.

To expand her business, Jalilah is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for buying more inventory of clothes which she can resell at markets in and around Kinoni.   Jalilah hopes to expand her clothes business, sell more product, and generate profit in order to help support her family.  


Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.name: God’S Mercy Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth D., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'God’s Mercy'. She is 42 years old, single, and has three children who range from 18 to 24 years old. She was only able to attend school through 8th grade due to lack of financial support.
 
For 15 years, she has been selling coconuts in Redlight Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 12,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 60,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more coconuts. She describes herself as a jovial woman. Her plan is to grow her business and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Meme is inset at lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more coconuts

loans.name: Herinques Paulo

texts.pt:
Henrique Paulo M. nasceu no Distrito de Macia, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, casado e pai de 3 filhos de 12, 8 e 2 anos de idade, os dois mais velhos vão a escola. Frequenta a escola na Universidade Pedagógica. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e  não sustenta mais ninguém para alem da sua famila.
Saiu de Gaza para Maputo atrás de emprego, mais tarde decidiu fixar sua residência e formar uma família. Trabalha como docente ha mais de 8 anos e é do quadro Ministério da Educação. Tem um salário de 4.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de colegas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 16.500.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, chapas de zinco e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. 
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir e mobilar a sua casa oferecendo melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Henrique Paulo M. was born in the District of Macia, Gaza Province, in southern Mozambique. He is married and the father of 3 children ages 12, 8, and 2. The two older children attend school. He attends classes at the Teachers University. He lives in his own home and does not support anyone other than his family. He left Gaza for Maputo in search of work. Later, he decided to establish residence there and start a family. He has been working as a teacher for more than 8 years, and is part of the Ministry of Education. He has a monthly salary of 4.500.00mt, which he uses for household expenses and saves a bit in his bank account. He has never had a loan in other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through colleagues who are also clients of this institution. This is his first loan, in the amount of 16,500.00mt, which he plans to use to purchase construction material (cement, zinc panels, etc.) to continue construction of his home. He promises to pay back the loan on schedule in order to have access to future loans. In the future he plans to request additional loans to complete and equip his home, in order to provide better living conditions to his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of construction mateiral (cement, zinc panels, etc.)

texts.en:

For 10 years, she has been selling stationery on Duport Road, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 45,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more stationery. She describes herself as a jovial woman.

Her plan is to grow her business and build a store.

loans.name: Fonk Sa Diekeur Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe FONK SA DIEKEUR est un des groupes de solidarité du Banc Villageois de RANDOULENE SUD, il est composé de 12 femmes toutes issues du même quartier. Elles sont toutes mariées et mères d'au moins de 03 enfants, à l’exception les deux qui accroupis à partir de la gauche de la photo. Elles développent des activités diverses, à savoir le petit commerce d'effets vestimentaires, de produits cosmétiques, de produits halieutiques, de chaussures. Par contre la responsable du groupe, en sus de son petit commerce fait de la restauration.

Madame Rokhaya G., debout à droite de la photo emmitouflée d’une écharpe noire portant des lunettes est la responsable du groupe de solidarité. Elle est âgée de 44 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants dont un seul garçon et 03 filles qui fréquentent l’école. Elle est vendeuse de chaussures et d’encens. En sus de ça elle vend sur une table de fortune installée devant chez elle le petit déjeuné. Elle mène cette activité depuis plus de 06 ans, elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité. L’objet de son financement est de développer et faire la promotion de son activité et l’objectif est de participer à la nourriture et la santé au niveau familiale et aussi d’assurer le payement de la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The group FONK SA DIEKEUR is one of the solidarity groups of the Banc Villageois of RANDOULENE SUD. It is composed of twelve women, all from the same district. They are all married mothers of at least three children, except the two grouped together from the left in the photo. The women are developing diverse businesses, namely small-scale commerce in clothing accessories, cosmetics, seafood, and shoes. By contrast, the group's leader works in food catering in addition to her small business. Ms. Rokhaya G. (who is standing at the right in the photo and bundled up in a black scarf and wearing glasses) is the leader of the solidarity group. She is 44 years old, married, and the mother of six children, of whom one boy and three girls are attending school. Rokhaya sells shoes and incense. In addition to this, she sells breakfast from a make-shift table set up in front of her home. She has been in this business for over six years. She has good experience in this business domain. The goal of her financing is to develop and advance her business in order to take part in the feeding and health care of her family and also to ensure that the children's schooling costs are covered.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing and advancing the businesses of her solidarity group

After realizing that her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, Jacqueline is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Jacqueline will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow her to keep reinvesting and saving for better financial stability.

loans.name: Ernesto Mapipo

texts.pt:
Ernesto Mapipo M. vive em Boane, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique. Tem um negócio próprio de compra e venda de arroz, no empréstimo passado conseguiu canalizar para o que esteve previsto e também foi suficiente. Conseguiu pagar a sua letra e ainda adiantava os seus pagamentos no seu calendário.
O seu negócio tem andado bem ultimamente, embora tenha sofrido um roubo no seu estabelecimento, onde foi um pouco difícil mas conseguiu superar. O presente empréstimo no valor de 26.000.00mt pretende comprar mais mercadoria (arroz, açúcar e outros) para aumentar a quantidade do stock. Com o rendimento do seu negócio conseguiu melhorar as condições de habitação no seio da família.
O empréstimo foi satisfatório, melhorou bastante a sua vida, por isso pretende solicitar mais crédito para aplicar no comércio, actividade que tem sustentado a sua vida.
texts.en:
Ernesto Mapipo M. lives in Boane, Maputo province, in southern Mozambique. He has his own business buying and selling rice. His past loan was used for the planned purpose and was sufficient. He was able to make his payments and even paid some of his payments early. His business has been going well lately, even though he suffered a robbery at his shop and it was a bit difficult to recover from it. The current loan is for 26.000.00mt, which he will use to purchase more products (rice, sugar, etc.) to increase his inventory. With the income from his business, he was able to improve his family's living conditions. The loan was satisfactory, and improved his life considerably. For this reason he is requesting an additional loan for his business, which has been his financial support.

Translated from Portuguese by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Recardina Nelma

texts.pt:
Recardina Nelma S. vive em Boane, província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique. Tem um negócio próprio de compra e venda de roupa nova diversa. No empréstimo passado foi possível comprar a mercadoria que esteve previsto, mas não foi suficiente para a quantidade desejada devido a alteração do preço no mercado de aquisição.
Conseguiu pagar a sua letra de acordo com o seu calendário e o seu negócio tem andado bem ultimamente. Com o rendimento do seu negócio conseguiu melhorar as condições de habitação no seio da família.

O empréstimo foi satisfatório, melhorou bastante a sua vida, por isso pretende solicitar mais crédito para comprar um míni bus para transportador público.
texts.en:
Recardina Nelma S. lives in Boane, Maputo province, in the south of Mozambique. She has her own business buying and selling various new clothing. With her previous loan, it was possible to purchase the merchandise she thought she would need, but it was not enough for the quantity she wanted due to the price changes in the market where she bought it. She managed to pay off her loan in the proper time, and her business has been going well lately. With the income from her business, she has managed to improve the living conditions of her family. With the present loan in the amount of 25,000 MT, she intends to buy more merchandise (blouses, skirts, pants, and other items) to increase the quantity of her stock. The loan was satisfactory, it improved her life a lot, and for this reason she intends to ask for more loans in order to buy a minibus to offer transportation service to the public.

Translated from Portuguese by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of more merchandise (blouses, skirts, pants, and other items)

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Fuad

texts.en: Fuad A. is 22 years old, a passionate young man who is engaged in cattle breeding. He has been running his business since 2009 and thanks to the best practice of his father, he learned very fast how to properly look after animals. He breeds calves, fattens them, and sells them to butcher shops and in the livestock bazaar. Fuad has applied for 500 AZN to purchase two calves.

loans.use: purchase two calves

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khanbala

texts.en: Khanbala F. is a 48-year-old beekeeper who works and lives in the small village of Agsu with his wife and four children. Quality honey is very expensive in Azerbaijan and takes a lot of time and effort to produce. Khanbala has been working very hard from May to October to produce quality honey since 2000. He has repeat clients who buy his honey and once a year he brings his products to the honey fair in Baku city which is 150 kilometers from his home village. Now Khanbala has applied for 800 AZN to purchase new beehives and improve his working conditions.

loans.use: purchase new beehives and improve working conditions

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Catarina Daniel

texts.pt:
Catarina Daniel C. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, casada e mãe de 3 filhos de 12, 7 e 3 anos de idade, os dois mais velhos vão a escola. Fez 10ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta seus sobrinhos que vivem com ela. 
Nunca saiu da sua cidade natal, tem um negócio e dono do mesmo ha mais de 6 anos e vende cerca de 25 refeições por dia. Não possui empregados e tem um rendimento de cerca de 4.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pedra, ferro, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 5.000.00mt e 10.000.00mt para habitação e bens.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir e mobilar a sua casa oferecendo melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família.
texts.en:
Catarina Daniel C. was born in the district of Boane, Maputo province, in the south of Mozambique. She is married and is the mother of three children aged 12, 7, and 3. The two older children go to school. She finished tenth grade, but didn't continue in school due to a lack of finances. She lives in her own house with her family and supports her nieces and nephews who live with her. Catarina never left her home town. She has her own business, and has owned it for more than six years, selling about 25 meals a day. She does not have employees, and earns an income of about 4,000 MT a month, which she uses for household expenses and still saves some in her bank account. She has never had loans from other banks, getting to know about Hluvuku through friends who are also clients of this institution. This is her third loan, in the amount of 15,000 MT, with which she plans to purchase construction materials (cement, stone, iron, sand, and other items) in order to continue the construction of her residence. The previous loans were for 5,000 and 10,000 MT for housing and goods. She promises to duly repay this loan in order to be able to receive others. In the future, she intends to request more loans in order to finish off and furnish her house, offering better living conditions for her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of construction material (cement, stone, iron, sand, and others items)

loans.name: Florencio

texts.en:
Florencio A. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. He is 59 years old. Florencio is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Florencio owns & operates a business buying scrap metal & other used-products such as bottles, plastics and empty plastic containers and selling it to the junk shops. Florencio has been engaged in his business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Florencio joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Florencio has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as additional working capital. Florencio is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more scrap items to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Florencio from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support education of his child. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Namiq

texts.en: Namiq Q. is a 38-year-old petty trader who sells different kinds of goods in the small market of Agsu city. He is married and has three children. Namiq sells candies, cookies, cigarettes and other such products. He works from early morning till late at night. His monthly turnover is 100AZN. He would like to increase his income by purchasing more goods for resale. For this purpose he has applied for a loan of 800 AZN.

loans.use: purchase more food merchandise

loans.name: Laurencia

texts.en:
Laurencia S. is from the village of Magting, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old. Laurencia is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Laurencia owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fruits and vegetables in the local community. Laurencia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Laurencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laurencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Laurencia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Laurencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josias

texts.en:
Josias is 32 years old, and he is married with two children who are 7 and 11 years old.  Josias makes a living by selling a variety of goods in his shop and this is his second successful year in this business.  Josias' shop hours are from 5 am to 10 pm every day.

After realizing that his capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, Josias is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Josias will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting and saving for better financial stability.  Josias will also take care of his children by providing enough food for them and sending them to a better school.

loans.use: A variety of goods including Fanta, bread, cosmetics, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, beans

loans.name: Ema Mucacho

texts.pt:
Ema Mucacho M. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, casada e mãe de 4 filhos de 12, 14, 17 e 21 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 5ą classe não continuou devido a guerra de desestabilização que assolou o pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém. 
Saiu de Namaacha para Boane quando se juntou ao seu marido. Tem um negócio e dono do mesmo ha mais de 18 anos, não possui empregados e tem um rendimento de cerca de 15.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária e através de Xitque (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua sobrinha que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (óleo, arroz, açúcar, cerveja, refrescos e outros produtos da primeira necessidade) para reforçar a mercadoria no seu negócio.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir casas tipo dependências para aluguer como forma de aumentar a renda familiar.
texts.en:
Ema Mucacho M. was born in the district of Namaacha, Maputo province, in the south of Mozambique. She is married and is the mother of four children, 12, 14, 17 and 21 years old. All of them go to school. She only has her grade five – her schooling was interrupted due to the destabilizing war that devastated the country. She lives in her own house with her family and has no other dependents. Ema left Namaacha for Boane when she married her husband. She has a business and has been the owner for more than 18 years. She does not have employees. She has an income of around 15,500 MT a month, which she uses for household expenses, and still saves some in her bank account and through the Xitique (a traditional rotational savings system). She has never had loans from other banks. She got to know about Hluvuku through her niece, who is also a client of this institution. This is her first loan in the amount of 15,000 MT, with which she plans to buy products (oil, rice, sugar, beer, soft drinks, and other basic necessities) to build up the merchandise in her business. She promises to duly repay this loan in order to be able to receive others. In the future, she plans to ask for more loans in order to built rooming-type houses to rent out as a means of augmenting her family income.

Translated from Portuguese by Heidi Petersen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of products (oil, rice, sugar, beer, soft drinks, and other basic necessities)

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora A. is currently in the business of selling local Sudanese bread, cooked by frying it in cooking oil, and she is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour.  Flora is 47 years old and is widowed.   She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more baking flour

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
N. Juliet is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children.  Two of her children are in school, and she also takes care of an additional dependent who is an orphan. Juliet has a business selling mats and other crafts, which she has had for several years.

To help expand her business, Juliet is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for buying more craft materials and other supplies for her to make her mats and other crafts.  Juliet hopes to have a more successful business and generate profit in order to support her children and the orphan she takes care of in their schooling.


Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Purchase arts and crafts materials

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda P. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 39 years old. Imelda is single and has one school-aged child . To make a living, Imelda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Imelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to  purchase additional products to sell. Imelda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Imelda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her child. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Jane is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a real charcoal store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Gilberto Arminda

texts.pt:
Gilberto Arminda L. nasceu no Distrito de Vilanculos, Província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique, casado e pai de 2 filhos de 03 e 06 anos de idade, a mais velha vai a escola. Fez somente 8ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta sua mãe e irmão que vivem com ele. 
Saiu de Inhambane para Boane com a sua mãe atrás do pai que trabalhava neste Distrito. Tem um negócio e dono do mesmo ha mais de 6 anos, não possui empregados e tem um rendimento de cerca de 4.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de mobilizações feitas pelos oficiais desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (óleo, arroz, açúcar e outros) para reforçar a mercadoria no seu negócio.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para melhorar as condições de habitação na sua família e iniciar uma criação de gado bovino e caprino.
texts.en:
Gilberto Arminda L. was born in the District of Vilanculos, Inhambane Province, in southern Mozambique. He is married and is the father of 2 children, who are 3 and 6 years old. The oldest goes to school. Gilberto only studied through the 8th grade; he didn't continue due to a lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and supports his mother and brother, who both live with him. He left Inhambane for Boane with his mother after his father went to work in that district. He has been the owner of his own business for more than 6 years. He does not have any employees and earns about 4,500 MZN per month, which he uses to pay for household expenses. He is even able to save some in his bank account. Gilberto never has had loans with other banks. He found out about Hluvuku through institution officials who were conducting enrollment campaigns. This is his 2nd loan, which has a value of 15,000 MZN. He plans to use it to buy supplies (cooking oil, rice, sugar, etc.) in order to build up his business's merchandise. He promises to pay back the loan on time so that he will be able to ask for others. In the future, he intends to ask for more loans in order to improve his family's living conditions and to start raising cattle and goats.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies (cooking oil, rice, sugar, etc.)

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
N. Zaituni is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka area of Uganda.  She is married and has 2 children.  One of her children is in school, and she takes care of another child who is also in school.  Zaituni has a business selling fish in Kalisizo.  Zaituni’s business serves the local community in Kalisizo by providing fresh fish to the other people in the village.

To help expand her business, Zaituni is requesting a loan of 100,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used for purchasing more fish to sell and also a basket to transport her fish to market.  Zaituni hopes to sell more fish in the future and generate profit in order to provide for her family.


Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  

These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: Buy more fish and a basket to transport fish to market

loans.name: Kerubo

texts.en:
Kerubo is 36 years old. She is a widowed mother of 4 children ages, 8, 12, 15, and 20. All the children are currently attending school. She is a farmer from Kisii town in Western Kenya. She has been farming for over 15 years and has employed two casual labourers. Her products are tea, cabbages, bananas, finger millet, and beans which she sells at the local market. She also earns income from her rental houses in the same area.

Kerubo's biggest challenge in farming is the poor transport network which makes it difficult to deliver products to the market and lack of enough skills in dairy farming.

Kerubo recently completed a previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES and has requested this loan of 45,000KES to purchase a water tank to harvest rain water for her dairy animals. This water tank will enable them to save a lot of time spent on fetching water from the river.

In future, she would like to own at least 3 quality dairy cows. She is grateful to Juhudi for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase a water tank

loans.name: Fauza Judas

texts.pt:
Fauza Judas S. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, casada e mãe de 6 filhos de idades entre 11 e 26 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez o ensino primário não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta 3 sobrinhos que vivem com ela. 
Saiu de Maputo para Boane quando ficou viúva do seu primeiro marido. Tem um negócio próprio ha mais de 25 anos de venda de tabaco em fardos. Não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento de cerca de 12.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (sacos de tabaco) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram no valor de 12.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade. 
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para aplicar na melhoria do seu negócio.
texts.en:
Fauza Judas S. was born in the city of Maputo, Maputo Province, in southern Mozambique. She is married and has 6 children, who are between 11 and 26 years old. All of them go to school. Fauza only completed elementary school; she did not continue due to a lack of financial resources. She lives in her own house with her family and supports 3 nieces and nephews who live with her. She left Maputo for Boane when she became widowed after the death of her first husband. She has had her own business selling bundles of tobacco for more than 25 years. She does not have any employees and earns about 12,000 MZN each month, which she uses to pay for expenses. She is even able to save some in her bank account. Fauza never has had loans with other banks. She found out about Hluvuku through friends who are also clients of this institution. This is her 3rd loan, which has a value of 20,000 MZN. She plans to use it to buy products (sacks of tobacco) to increase her stock. The previous loans were for 12,000 MZN and 15,000 MZN, both for the same purpose. She promises to pay back the loan on time so that she will be able to have access to others. In the future, she intends to request more loans to help improve her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products (sacks of tobacco)

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 40 years old. She is married with 4 children who are all adults now. She is a farmer from Nyamira town in Western Kenya where she has been farming for 20 years. She has employed  one person from her community to help with the farm work. Her products are maize, milk, and tea which she sells at the local market. Her major challenge has been the limited availability of animal feed due to dry seasons and also, animal diseases.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 60,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. This loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for sale. The extra income from this loan will enable her to improve the living standard of her family.

Jane intends to purchase another piece of land and buy more dairy cows in future. She says that she is willing to work with Juhudi for as long as it takes.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom is 38 years old. He is married with 5 children between the ages of 4 and 17. All the children are currently attending school. He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya where he has been farming for 20 years. His products are maize and milk which he sells locally. He also owns a posho mill (making cornmeal) and a power saw for lumbering. His biggest challenge in farming has been the high prices of dairy feed and animal diseases which affect trade.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for 31,200 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. Through the sale of milk from this dairy cow, Tom will be able to increase his sources of income which will enable him to meet the family's basic needs.

He is grateful to Juhudi for uplifting the lives of small-scale farmers.

loans.use: To purchase and insure  a dairy cow

loans.name: Gilbert

texts.en:
36-year-old Gilbert is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. He is married with four children between the ages of 4 months and 15 years old. Three of the children are currently attending school.

Gilbert has been practising mixed farming for 18 years and has employed 3 casual labourers. His main products are milk, maize, beans, tomatoes and cabbages that he sells at the local market. He also buys and sells dairy cows and goats. His biggest challenge in this business has been weather conditions which affect his animal feed and diseases which attack his dairy cows.

He has requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo of 41,600 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to meet the family's basic needs.

In 5 years' time, he hopes to have increased his productivity and hence earn enough income. He hopes Juhudi will continue to fund him so that he is able to do different projects.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more phones and phone accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Additional liters for sale and the purchase of a machine for boiling milk

loans.name: Jokoi Lo Mita Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes que conforman el  comité Jakoi lo Mita, de la zona de Santiago, se dedican al trabajo doméstico  y a la venta de los  productos que las mismas producen en sus casas.
Los días domingos organizan sorteos de sabanas y colchas que ellas mismas bordan y así contribuyen para el fondo común que les ayudara con los pagos del créditos y contar con ahorro.
Son vecinas y comparten las reuniones donde planifican las posibles actividades que estaran realizando.
Una de la integrantes es la señora Ana Maria quien se dedica a la venta de comestibles que ella misma prepara en su casa, con los productos que ella produce, en general ella cocina utilizando ingredientes caceros.
Los comitibles que ella prepara lo traslada en bus hasta el mercado donde en pocas horas vende todo lo que lleva.
Esta tarea de levantarse muy temprano a la mañana, preparar todo, salir y vender sus productos lo realiza cada mañana muy temprano, asi ella puede ganar dinero para los gastos de alimentacion diaria para su familia.
Solicita el prestamo para la compra de vianda grandes que facilitará el traslado de los comestibles.
texts.en:
The members of the Santiago area Jakoi lo Mita committee are domestic workers who sell homemade products. On Sundays, they organize raffles of hand-embroidered sheets and quilts. They contribute the proceeds to the common fund which helps them pay their loans and build their savings account. They are neighbors and hold meetings to plan activities. One of the members, Ms. Ana Maria, sells food that she prepares herself in her home. Usually, she cooks with homemade ingredients using home grown products. The food that she prepares is transported by bus to the market where she sells everything in a few hours. In order to earn money to feed her family, she gets up very early every morning to prepare everything and then go to the market to sell her products. The loan is for the purchase of large lunch boxes which will make it easier to transport the food.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Francoletti-Putz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of lunch boxes

loans.name: Estelita

texts.en:
Estelita E. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 51 years old. Estelita is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Estelita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products. Estelita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Estelita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Estelita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Estelita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Godfroid

texts.fr:
N. Godefroid a 38 ans, née à Ngoma dans l’ancien préfecture de Kibungo aujourd’hui se trouve dans la province de l’Est du Rwanda. Marie il a 4 enfants, le plus âgée a 7 ans et le moins âgée à 3 ans.il est Evangéliste de l’Eglise ADEPR (association des églises de pentecôte).
Il s’est donnée  à l’Eglise pour l’évangélisation après avoir été démobilisé dans  les forces de défense Rwandais (Rwanda defense force RDF).
Ses épargnes successives lui a permit de se marier et amener ses enfants a l’école, malgré son petit salaire.
Il vient de contracter un prêt avec ACB pour acheter les matériels et ou équipements de la maison qui sont salon, armoire, téléviseur, pour équiper s maison. Dans le passé, il a soldé  sept autres prêts. Avec ses épargnes il compte lui et sa femme continuer les études,  il sera promu au poste de Pasteur de l’église. Il souhaite aussi avoir sa maison car il loue l’habitation aujourd’hui.
texts.en:
N. Godefroid is 38 years old and was born in Ngoma, in the former prefecture of Kibungo, found today in the East Province of Rwanda. He is married and has four children. The eldest is 7 years old and the youngest is 3. Godefroid is the assistant pastor of the ADEPR (Association des Eglises de Pentecôte) Church. He has devoted all his time to the Church in evangelizing after having been demobilized from the Rwandan defense force (RDF). His successive savings have enabled him to get married and send his children to school despite his small salary. Godefroid just signed a loan with ACB in order to buy supplies and/or home furnishings that include a living room set, dresser, and television. In the past, he has settled seven other loans. With his savings, he himself and his wife plan on continuing in school. He will be promoted to the position of church pastor. He also wishes to obtain a house because he is currently renting.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying home furnishings

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jaqueline was born 1972, and she is a widow with 3 children. Jaqueline sells cooking oil, and this business is profitable where she lives.  Jaqueline is seasoned in her business because she has an experience of 5 years in her field. The hours of her daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day.

Jaqueline is now requesting her second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business and serving more customers. With this loan Jaqueline will be able to earn more profit which will help her sort out her family problems.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Nancy Chrislene

texts.fr:
Femme commercante de 29 ans,celibataire ayant a sa charge un enfant,exerce le commerce de la vente des meches depuis bientot 4 ans ,et elle  vend en moyenne 12000 a 15000 frs par jour
Avec  ce pret elle compte acheter des differentes qualites de meches, tout models de tissage a la mode ces derniers temps, et les produits de beaute comme les  cremes demelantes,cremes pour entretenir le cuir chevelu

   Comme son etalage est dans le plus grand marche de Brazzaville , elle use de beaucoup de strategies pour attirer sa clientele, et presenter les meilleurs prix a ses potentiels clients qui sont dans les environs
  A l'avenir elle pense s'inscrire dans un institut de beaute pour se perfectionner et a la fin de sa formation ouvrir un salon de coiffure pour dames; Tres joviale; elle attire tout le monde par sa gentillesse
texts.en:
A 29-year old businesswoman, single with one child in her care, in the business of selling hair extensions for almost 4 years. She sells an average of 12,000 to 15,000 francs per day. With this loan she intends to buy different quality hair extensions, all types of weaves in current styles, and beauty products such as conditioners and scalp creams. Since her display is in the biggest market in Brazzaville, she uses many strategies to attract customers and offer the best prices to potential clients in the area. In the future she plans to enroll in a beauty school to perfect her technique, and after her training she would like to open a women’s hair salon. Very cheerful, she draws in everyone with her kindness.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions, weaves and beauty products

loans.name: Rosario Lucy

texts.es:
La Señora Rosario Lucy A. F.  está casada por más de 20 años con el Señor Juan Fanor Medrano Villegas,  tienen 1 hija las cuales acuden a la escuela de la zona todas las mañanas y por las tardes ayuda a su mama con el cuidado de las vacas. 

La Señora Rosario vive en la Zona conocida como Maica Norte en Cochabamba, donde tiene vacas, cuya leche vende a una empresa que se encarga de elaborar diferentes productos lácteos, por más de 10 años que vende toda su producción de leche cruda a esta empresa.

La Señora Rosario ya obtuvo 2 créditos anteriores con nuestra institución y demostró ser una persona muy trabajadora y responsable, además desde el primer crédito hasta la fecha duplico su producción de leche y la cantidad  de vacas que tiene. Nos cuenta que su mayor sueño es ver a su hija ser buena profesional y que tenga una vida mejor que la que tuvo ella y si Dios quiere vivir lo suficiente para poder ver a su hija casada y con muchos hijos.
texts.en:
Rosario Lucy A. F. has been maried to Jan Fanor Medrano Villegas for over 20 years. They have one daughter. She goes to the local school every morning, and in the afternoon she helps her mother take care of the cows. Rosario lives in the area known as Maica Norte in Cochabamba. She has cows there, and she sells their milk to a company that makes different dairy products. She has been selling all of her raw milk production to this company for over ten years. Rosario has had two previous loans with our institution. She has demonstrated herself to be a very hard-working and responsible person. Also, from the time of her first loan up until now she doubled her milk production and the number of cows that she has. She tells us that her biggest dream is to see her daughter become a professional and have a better life than Rosario had. Also, God willing, she wants to live long enough to be able to see her daughter married with lots of children.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Nimfa L. is from the village of Bonbon, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 35 years old. Nimfa is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Nimfa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture selling coconut and coconut products. Another source of income for the family comes from selling grilled chicken and pork and hot dogs. Nimfa usually does this every night. Nimfa has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nimfa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nimfa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used  purchase more coconuts to sell. Nimfa is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business, both the coconut business and her food business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nimfa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Venantie

texts.en:
Venantie was born in 1957 and is married with five children. She owns a business selling milk and cakes.   Before having this business, Venantie was a farmer but she could not earn much money doing that. Venantie employs two people from her community. Venantie works every day from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening. 

Venantie is now requesting a loan from Kiva Lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing her business through purchasing a lot of milk and other products needed by her customers. With this loan she will be able to earn more profit which will be used in the expansion of her business.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Unidas De Potrerito Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes que conforman el  comité Unidas de Potrerito realizan todo tipo de trabajos domésticos,  tienen su propia huerta, cultivan sus productos para luego venderlos dentro y fuera de la comunidad. Todas ellas son vecinas del barrio y trabajan muy unidades en cada actividad que realizan.

Una de las integrantes es la señora Susana quien se dedica actualmente al servicio domésticos en varias casas de familia, ella realiza trabajo como, lavado y planchado de ropas, limpieza en general  y cocina. Ella trabaja un día entero fuera de su casa por lo su deseo es la de contar con un negocio  que le pueda ayudar con los gastos y a al mismo tiempo pueda quedarse en su casa y trabajar desde ahí.

Es por ello que su ella esta comenzando con la actividad de venta de ropas y por solicita el préstamo para la compra de ropas de invierno (suéter, pantalones, camperas) en general con lo que ira aumentando su clientela y al mismo tiempo su ingreso.
texts.en:
The members who make up the committee Unidas de Potrerito [United Women of Potrerito] carry out all manner of domestic labor. They have their own garden plot where they cultivate their products which they sell both within the community and beyond. They are all residents of the same neighborhood and work together closely in every job they do. One of the members is Susana who currently is providing domestic services in various family homes. She does work such as laundry and ironing, general cleaning and cooking. She works all day long outside her home; therefore, her wish is to have a business that helps her with expenses in which she can stay at home and work from there. She is requesting this loan to buy winter clothing (sweaters, pants, jackets) so that she can start selling clothing. In this way, she hopes to expand her income and her client base.

Translated from Spanish by Margaret Wolfe-Roberts, Kiva Volunteer
